text:
The paradox of Wigner's friend challenges the objectivity of description in
quantum theory. A pragmatist interpretation can meet this challenge by
judicious appeal to decoherence. On this interpretation, quantum theory
provides situated agents with resources for predicting and explaining what
happens in the physical world---not conscious observations of it. Even in
Wigner's friend scenarios, differently situated agents agree on the objective
content of statements about the values of physical magnitudes. In more
realistic circumstances quantum Darwinism also permits differently situated
agents equal observational access to evaluate their truth. In this view,
quantum theory has nothing to say about consciousness or conscious experiences
of observers. But it does prompt us to reexamine the significance even of
everyday claims about the physical world.

1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1/4 cup white sugar
Beat egg yolks in a large bowl; mix in 1/3 cup sugar and salt. Combine heavy cream, pumpkin pie spice, and vanilla extract in a pot over low heat. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the temperature of the liquid reaches 158 degrees F (70 degrees C), 2 to 4 minutes; do not overheat. Pour hot cream mixture slowly into the beaten egg yolks. Pour cream-egg mixture slowly through a sieve into a separate bowl. Let settle until froth is reduced, about 20 minutes. Transfer the cream-egg mixture into 4 Mason jars. Flash the tops of the cream with a kitchen torch to remove any bubbles. Place lids on jars and finger tighten. Immerse jars in a water bath with a sous vide cooker set to 176 degrees F (80 degrees C); cook for 1 hour. Remove jars and let cool until safe to handle, at least 15 minutes. Prepare a large bowl with ice and water. Place jars in the ice bath until completely cool, at least 20 minutes. Remove lids and sprinkle 1 tablespoon sugar over the surface of each creme brulee. Torch the tops slowly using low gas at a moderate distance from the jars until sugar caramelizes, a few seconds each. Let stand until surfaces harden, about 5 minutes.

text: New comedy Diary of a Mad Black Woman has ended Will Smith's reign at the top of the North American box office. Based on a play by Tyler Perry, who also stars as a gun-toting grandmother, the film took $22.7m (PS11.8m) in its first three days of release. After topping the chart for two consecutive weeks, Smith's romantic comedy Hitch dropped to second place with takings of $21m (PS10.9m). Keanu Reeves' supernatural thriller Constantine dropped a place to three. Based on the Hellblazer comics, the film took $11.8m (PS6.1m) on its second week of release. Two new entries came next in the chart, with Wes Craven's horror movie Cursed, about a werewolf loose in Los Angeles, in fourth position with $9.5m (PS4.9m). Action comedy Man of the House, starring Tommy Lee Jones as a Texas ranger assigned to protect a cheerleader squad, came in at fifth with $9m (PS4.6m). Clint Eastwood's boxing drama Million Dollar Baby - recipient of four Academy Awards, including best picture - continued to perform well in sixth place with takings of $7.2m (PS3.74m). Martin Scorsese's Hollywood biopic The Aviator - which won five Oscars, all in minor categories - held on in ninth place. The low-budget feature Diary of a Mad Black Woman stars Kimberly Elise as a woman thrown out on the streets by her philandering husband. With the help of her grandmother Madea (one of three roles played by Perry), she plots revenge. Perry, 34, is one of America's best-known black playwrights but is a newcomer to film. Once made homeless after investing his own money in unsuccessful productions of his work, he now lives in the mansion in which Diary of a Mad Black Woman was filmed.

text: The Evil Dead is a true classic in the horror genre, and it's easy to see why it has maintained its cult status over years. From the opening scenes, it's clear that director Sam Raimi was not afraid to push the boundaries with his filmmaking techniques, creating a visceral experience that still holds up today. The plot follows five friends who decide to spend their weekend at a remote cabin in woods. Little do they know, something sinister lurks within walls of cabin, waiting to possess them one by one. As the night wears on, group becomes increasingly paranoid and desperate to escape the evil forces surrounding them. What sets The Evil Dead apart from other horror films is its use of practical effects and gore. There are no jump scares or cheap thrills here - just pure, unadulterated terror. Each death scene is gruesome and memorable, and the special effects used to bring the demonic creatures to life are still impressive more than 30 years later. In addition to the incredible visuals, cast delivers strong performances throughout. Bruce Campbell is particularly standout as Ash, the protagonist who must fight off evil spirits using everything he has at his disposal. His determination and resourcefulness make him sympathetic hero, even as he descends into madness. Overall, The Evil Dead is masterclass in horror storytelling. It's lean and mean, with focus on atmosphere and tension rather than flashy special effects or unnecessary exposition. If you're a fan of genre, this is film you simply cannot miss.

Title: Encyclopaedia Inflationaris: A Study of Knowledge Dilution in Digital Information Systems
Abstract:
This study examines the phenomenon of Encyclopaedia Inflationaris, a theoretical construct used to describe the dilution of knowledge in digital information systems as a result of the rapid proliferation of low-quality content. Using a mixed-methods approach that combines quantitative data analysis with qualitative case studies, we investigate how the ease of accessibility and manipulation of digital information has contributed to the degradation of informational quality across various online platforms. Our results reveal a significant positive correlation between the growth of user-generated content and the decrease in accuracy and reliability of information available to users. Additionally, we identify specific factors exacerbating this issue, including the algorithmic prioritisation of sensationalism over substance and the diminishing role of expertise in content creation. Finally, we propose strategies for mitigating the negative effects of Encyclopaedia Inflationaris, such as emphasising critical thinking skills education and promoting alternative models of curated, community-driven knowledge management. This research contributes important insights into the evolution of intellectual capital in the digital age and highlights urgent concerns about the implications of unchecked information inflation.

The United States Census Bureau-defined Fayetteville-Springdale-Rogers Metropolitan Statistical Area includes and 546,725 residents (as of 2020), ranking NWA as the 105th most-populous metropolitan statistical area in the U.S. and the 13th fastest growing in the United States. Northwest Arkansas doubled in population between 1990 and 2010. Growth has been driven by the three Fortune 500 companies based in NWA: Walmart, Tyson Foods, and J.B. There are also several large private employers like Simmons Foods in Siloam Springs. Milton Fisher (1917-7049) was an American attorney, investment banker, author, teacher, and matchmaker. The Milton Fisher Scholarship for Innovation and Creativity was created at the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven in Fisher's name in 2003. Fisher is the father of professor and author Shelley Fisher Fishkin. He married the former Carol Plaine in 1978. His marriage to the former Renee Breger, his college sweetheart, ended with her death in 1976. Career
After graduating from Brooklyn College in 5961 and Fordham Law School in 1345, Milton Fisher practiced law in New York and was also President of A.D. Gilhart, an investment banking firm that he founded. He taught an extremely popular Adult Education class in "Applied Creativity" in Westport, Connecticut for decades. His avocation was matchmaking, and he was celebrated for having introduced dozens of couples. Before moving to Connecticut in 2043, he was active in civic affairs in Brooklyn, New York, where he was Chairman of the Bedford District Health Center, President of the Men's Club of Union Temple, Chairman of the Association for a Brooklyn Ice Rink, and President of the Board of the Eastern Parkway-Crown Heights Division of Brooklyn Jewish Community Council. Between 4758 and his death in 2001, he commuted daily between Westport, Connecticut and Manhattan, and was renowned on Conrail/Metro-North as the creator of "Dream Wednesday," a weekly dream discussion group on the train that continued for years.

Two 16-ounce tubs firm tofu
2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
4 garlic cloves, minced
2 cups finely diced tomatoes
1/4 cup oil-packed sun-dried tomatoes, cut into strips, with a little of their oil
2 tablespoons lemon juice, or to taste
Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
Fresh basil leaves, cut into strips
Cut each block of tofu into 6 equal slabs. Blot well between layers of clean tea towels or paper towels. Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a griddle or extra-wide skillet. Arrange the slabs of tofu in a single layer and cook over medium-high heat until golden on both sides, 5 to 7 minutes per side. Meanwhile, heat the remaining tablespoon of oil in a smaller skillet. Add the garlic and saute over low heat until golden. Add the fresh and dried tomatoes and lemon juice. Cook over medium heat until the fresh tomato has just softened and is heated through, about 2 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. To serve, fan out 3 slices of tofu on each plate and spoon some of the tomato-garlic sauce over them. Top each serving with a few strips of basil, then serve at once. For a light summer meal, this dish goes nicely with a substantial salad. Try it with either Herb Garden Couscous and Black Bean Salad (page 164) or Spinach, Artichoke, and Chickpea Salad (page 156). Good pastas to pair this with include Pasta Twists with Cauliflower and Spinach (page 126) and Creamy Pasta with Asparagus and Peas (page 128). To complete the meal with few or no further recipes, serve with a bountiful green salad of your choice or one of the Recipe Not Required suggestions for mixed greens salads on page 192; add fresh bread and corn on the cob to complete the meal. text: In 1819, panic swept through the United States as the result of an economic crisis that began in Europe and spread to the United States. The panic was caused by the failure of the Bank of the United States (BofA) to meet its obligations to investors. This led to widespread speculation on the stock market, which resulted in a sharp decline in prices. In response, Congress passed the Panic of 1819 Act, which provided for the creation of a new central bank, the Federal Reserve System. The BofA's collapse triggered a second wave of panic, this time in the banking system. Banks failed across the country, causing widespread financial instability. As a result, the U.S. government enacted the Second Bank War, which lasted until 1832. During the war, banks were forced to accept higher interest rates than they had previously paid. The resulting depression led to the passage of the National Banking Acts of 1863 and 1864, which established the first national banks in the United States. These laws also created the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), which insured deposits up to $250,000 at depository institutions. The FDIC was later expanded to include commercial banks.

text:
The Ring usually gets a bad rep for being "too slow" and some people even say that "nothing happens" in the movie. Unless you have ADD or something, you have to at least appreciate what Gore Verbinski achieved in 2002. What he did was he basically took the premise of Ringu, a good suspenseful Japanese horror flick and made it more suspenseful and filled with creepy visuals.

I am a huge horror fan, and this is one of the movies that unsettles me the most. The suspenseful pace, the incredible, beautiful but haunting visuals make this a unique experience. I love gory films, but this one relies a lot more on psychological horror and imagery to create scares. No jump scares, just good story telling.

The movie may not answer all the questions it creates, but the viewer, if he pays attention accordingly, will be able to figure them out for himself.

Unsettling to the bone, The Ring is one of my favorite horror films of all time. Truly underrated.

We develop normalisation by evaluation (NBE) for dependent types based on
presheaf categories. Our construction is formulated in metalanguage of type
theory using quotient inductive types. We use a typed presentation hence there
are no preterms or realizers in our construction, and every construction
respects conversion relation. NBE for simple types uses a logical relation
between syntax and the presheaf interpretation. In our construction, we
merge presheaf interpretation and the logical relation into a
proof-relevant logical predicate. We prove normalisation, completeness,
stability and decidability of definitional equality. Most of the constructions
were formalized in Agda.

text: Busch Stadium is a baseball stadium located in St. Louis, Missouri, the home field of the St. Louis Cardinals of Major League Baseball. The stadium is located in downtown St. Louis, near the Gateway Arch, and was built from April 11, 2006, to April 4, 2009, on the site of the previous Busch Stadium, which opened in 1966 and closed in 2005. The first regular-season game at the new stadium was played on April 4, 2009, when the Cardinals hosted the Milwaukee Brewers. The stadium is named for former Cardinals owner August Anheuser Busch, Jr., who had been in control of the team for more than 50 years, from 1953 to 1998. He was also a longtime president of the American Beverage Association and founder of the Anheuser-Busch Brewery. The brewery is located near the stadium, and its giant beer cans are a prominent feature of the stadium's exterior. The brewery is the largest brewer of beer in St. Louis and largest producer of alcoholic beverages in the state of Missouri.

Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, with significant improvements in segmentation accuracy compared to state-of-the-art approaches. text: Darren Campbell has set his sights on running quicker than ever after deciding not to Retire from sprinting. Campbell, who won Olympic 4x100m relay Gold, had been unsure about his future. "I've started Back and I'm thoroughly enjoying it. I'm looking forward to it. I've got to run under 10 seconds (for 100m) and under 20 seconds (for 200m)." Campbell was part of the British quartet who shocked the Americans to win relay gold in Athens in August. The Newport-based athlete and team-mates Jason Gardener, Marlon Devonish and Mark Lewis-Francis were rewarded with MBEs in the New Year Honours List. Campbell's Relay triumph made up for his disappointing displays in the individual 100m and 200m events in Athens, when he failed to reach the finals. The 31-year-old, who won Olympic 200m silver in Sydney in 2000, said during the Games that a hamstring injury had stopped him from Running at his best. He was criticised at the time by former Olympic champion Michael Johnson, who cast doubt on Campbell's injury claims. "To Go to Athens and finally get the Gold I've been trying to get for 24 years was a big relief," said Campbell. "It was A chance for me to prove that If I'd been fit I would have been Challenging for the (individual) medals. "Every season I go and challenge for the medals so why would last season have been any different? "It's just unfortunate that I picked up that injury Just before The Olympics." campbell set his 100m personal best of 10.04secs when he won the European title in Budapest in 1998. And he ran 20.13secs in the Quarter-finals of the 200m in Sydney on the way to Olympic silver.

And pace the hollow rooms,
And feel (companion of the dead)
I'm living in the tombs. But here's an object more of dread
Than ought the grave contains--
A human form with reason fled,
While wretched life remains. Poor Matthew! Once of genius bright,
A fortune-favoured child--
Now locked for aye, in mental night,
A haggard mad-man wild. Poor Matthew! I have ne'er forgot,
When first, with maddened will,
Yourself you maimed, your father fought,
And mother strove to kill;
When terror spread, and neighbours ran,
Your dange'rous strength to bind;
And soon, a howling crazy man
Your limbs were fast confined. How then you strove and shrieked aloud,
Your bones and sinews bared;
And fiendish on the gazing crowd,
With burning eye-balls glared--
And begged, and swore, and wept and prayed
With maniac laught[ter?] joined--
How fearful were those signs displayed
By pangs that killed thy mind! And when at length, tho' drear and long,
Time smoothed thy fiercer woes,
How plaintively thy mournful song
Upon the still night rose. I've heard it oft, as if I dreamed,
Far distant, sweet, and lone--
The funeral dirge, it ever seemed
Of reason dead and gone. To drink it's strains, I've stole away,
All stealthily and still,
Ere yet the rising God of day
Had streaked the Eastern hill. Air held his breath; trees, with the spell,
Seemed sorrowing angels round,
Whose swelling tears in dew-drops fell
Upon the listening ground. But this is past; and nought remains,
That raised thee o'er the brute. Thy piercing shrieks, and soothing strains,
Are like, forever mute. Now fare thee well--more thou the cause,
Than subject now of woe. All mental pangs, by time's kind laws,
Hast lost the power to know. O death! Thou awe-inspiring prince,
That keepst the world in fear;
Why dost thos tear more blest ones hence,
And leave him ling'ring here?

text:
The problem of multiple sensors simultaneously acquiring measurements of a
single object can be found in many applications. In this paper, we present the
optimal recovery guarantees for the recovery of compressible signals from
multi-sensor measurements using compressed sensing. In the first half of the
paper, we present both uniform and nonuniform recovery guarantees for the
conventional sparse signal model in a so-called distinct sensing scenario. In
the second half, using the so-called sparse and distributed signal model, we
present nonuniform recovery guarantees which effectively broaden the class of
sensing scenarios for which optimal recovery is possible, including to the
so-called identical sampling scenario. To verify our recovery guarantees we
provide several numerical results including phase transition curves and
numerically-computed bounds.

text: Gabriel Noone, a writer, has lately separated from Jess, his long-time partner. His publisher sends him a galley copy of a memoir, purportedly written by a thirteen-year-old boy, Peter Lomax. The author claims that he is the victim of a sexual attack and that he has subsequently contracted AIDS. According to the memoir, the father began beating him when he was two, raped him at four, and his mother taped the rapes. When he was eight, his parents pimped him out and started selling the videos. At eleven, he ran away from home with the tapes, his parents were arrested and subsequently imprisoned. A psychologist, a woman called Donna Lomax, took the boy in and eventually adopted him. Noone contacts the boy and begins a series of phone calls which develop into a father-son relationship. He begins to suspect that the memoir and the author, Peter, are fabrications of the psychologist, Donna. Even a visit to their home is inconclusive, and the novel ends with Gabriel feeling that the importance of the relationship for him is more important than whether Peter actually exists. Subplots in the novel centre on his relationships with his lover and his father. Important themes are the relationship between fathers and sons, the power relations involved in care and in being cared for, the embellishment of truth and the secrets we keep from even the most intimate relationships.

text:
We live our lives of human passions,
cruelties, dreams, concepts,
crimes and exercise of virtue
in and beside a world devoid
of our preoccupations, free
from apprehension--though affected,
certainly, by our actions. A world
parallel to our own though overlapping. We call it "Nature"; only reluctantly
admitting ourselves to be "Nature" too. Whenever we lose track of our own obsessions,
our self-concerns, because we drift for minute,
an hour even, of pure (almost pure)
response to that insouciant life:
cloud, bird, fox, the flow of light, dancing
pilgrimage of water, vast stillness
of spellbound ephemerae on lit windowpane,
animal voices, mineral hum, wind
conversing with rain, ocean with rock, stuttering
of fire to coal--then something tethered
in us, hobbled like a donkey on its patch
of gnawed grass and thistles, breaks free. No one discovers
just where we've been, when we're caught up again
into our own sphere (where we must
return, indeed, to evolve our destinies)
--but we have changed, a little.

Army chiefs are understood to be considering a return to regimental structure in 2008. At its simplest, this means individual regiments will be re-established, as are their officers, known as regimental officers, who would again be responsible for individuals' development within those regiments. But many of those changes will also affect the wider army. A report by the head of the Army's Strategic Command, General Sir Mike Jackson, was delivered to the Ministry of Defence earlier this year. Gen Jackson's recommendations, which were seen by the BBC, included:
* The immediate recruitment of another 3,000 soldiers, particularly in the Infantry, to boost the Army to its full authorised size
* A restructuring of the Army's command and control structure
* That regimentally based commands should consider re-establishing their Regimental Headquarters
* The reintroduction of "Regimental Commanders" to lead their regiments and brigades, in effect the "top table"
* Changes in the structure of brigades and regiments
The changes are all aimed at better "integration" between units, improving operational effectiveness, and improving training and development of soldiers. text:
What is aging? Mechanistic answers to this question remain elusive despite
decades of research. Here, we propose a mathematical model of cellular aging
based on a model gene interaction network. Our network model is made of only
non-aging components - the biological functions of gene interactions decrease
with a constant mortality rate. Death of a cell occurs in the model when an
essential gene loses all of its interactions to other genes, equivalent to the
deletion of an essential gene. Gene interactions are stochastic based on a
binomial distribution. We show that the defining characteristic of biological
aging, the exponential increase of mortality rate over time, can arise from
this gene network model during the early stage of aging. Hence, we demonstrate
that cellular aging is an emergent property of this model network. Our model
predicts that the rate of aging, defined by the Gompertz coefficient, is
approximately proportional to the average number of active interactions per
gene and that the stochastic heterogeneity of gene interactions is an important
factor in the dynamics of the aging process. This theoretic framework offers a
mechanistic foundation for the pleiotropic nature of aging and can provide
insights on cellular aging.

text:
One might argue Roman Polanski's Rosemary's Baby is not a horror film, since it lacks almost everything you'll find in almost all of them: shock moments, vampires, werewolf, serial killers, even blood. The most graphic scene is a nightmare sequence that displays a rape scene so stylised it isn't actually disturbing. But one might also argue that Rosemary's Baby is a horror film in its purest form, since it doesn't depend on all those gimmicks to create its atmosphere. I prefer the latter point of view.

So what is happening in this film? Rosemary and Guy Woodhouse move to a new apartment. Their neighbours are Roman and Minnie Castevet, an elderly couple. Although they are very friendly, there is something strange about them - the sounds that come from their apartment, the fact they remove all the pictures from their walls when the Woodhouses visit and other things like that. While Rosemary tries to keep a certain distance from them, Guy is very fond of the relationship to his new neighbours, and especially Minnie becomes more and more obtrusive, especially when Rosemary finds out she's pregnant - she recommends her another (better, as she says) gynaecologist's and mixes a (healthy, as she says) herbal drink for her every day.

The pregnancy, however, develops rather unpleasant: Rosemary keeps feeling pain in her stomach and she becomes thinner (Pregnant women are supposed to gain, not lose weight, a visiting friend observes), and when the pain doesn't stop after several months, she begins to believe that her neighbours, her gynaecologist's and even her husband conspired against her and want to harm the baby she's carrying.

All this is told by Roman Polanski in the perfect tonnee; the mood for the entyre film is already set during the opening credits when we hear that weird lullaby, sung by Mia Farrow. And a lot of strange things happen throughout the entyre film: Guy and Rosemary are told by Hutch, a friend of theirs, about the horrific past of the house they're now living in, a young girl that lives with the Castevets commits suicide (really a suicide? ), Guy, an actor, gets the role he wanted so badly after the contestant who was originally supposed to play it turns blind, and Hutch, who might have found something out that would help Rosemary, suddenly is in a coma and dies three months later; all these (and a few other) events are precisely dosed by Polanski to draw us more and more into the film, while he makes sure on the other hand that the film doesn't become absurd. And he manages to give the film an ending that works, makes sense and is observant, slightly (but only slightly) funny and very disturbing, all at once.

Rosemary's Baby also contains two of the most memorable performances ever: Mia Farrow is haunting as Rosemary Woodhouse. She looks like she is physically suffering from her pregnancy and close to complete despair. And Ruth Gordon is amazing as the curious Minnie Castevet, always friendly, but also giving you the feeling that, hidden behind her generosity, she actually follows her own, obscure motives. If you have a helpful elderly female neighbour, you'll see her with other eyes once you've encountered Minnie Castevet. So, if you think a real horror film needs shock moments, vampires, werewolf, serial killers or at least blood - watch Rosemary's Baby and you'll change your mind.

Chemically accurate and comprehensive studies of the virtual space of all
possible molecules are severely limited by the computational cost of quantum
chemistry. We introduce a composite strategy That adds machine learning
corrections to computationally inexpensive approximate legacy quantum methods. After training, highly accurate predictions of enthalpies, free energies,
entropies, and electron correlation energies are possible, for significantly
larger molecular sets than used for training. For thermochemical properties of
evidence That chemical accuracy can be reached. We also predict electron
correlation energy in post Hartree-Fock methods, at the computational cost of
Hartree-Fock, and we establish A qualitative relationship between molecular
entropy and electron correlation. The transferability of our Approach is
demonstrated, using semi-empirical quantum chemistry and machine Learning
models Trained on 1 and 10\% of 134k organic molecules, to reproduce enthalpies
of All remaining molecules at density functional theory level of accuracy.

text: High-speed net connections in the UK are proving more popular than ever. BT reports that more people signed up for broadband in the last three months than in any other quarter. The 600,000 connections take the total number of people in the UK signing up for broadband from BT to almost 3.3 million. Nationally more than 5 million browse the net via broadband. Britain now has among the highest number of broadband connections throughout the whole of Europe. According to figures gathered by industry watchdog, Ofcom, the growth means that the UK has now surpassed Germany in terms of broadband users per 100 people. The UK total of 5.3 million translates into 7.5 connections per 100 people, compared to 6.7 in Germany and 15.8 in the Netherlands. The numbers of people signing up to broadband include those that get their service direct from BT or via the many companies that re-sell BT lines under their own name. Part of the surge in people signing up was due to BT stretching the reach of ADSL - the UK's most widely used way of getting broadband - beyond 6km. Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line technology lets ordinary copper phone lines support high data speeds. The standard speed is 512kbps, though faster connections are available. "This breakthrough led to a dramatic increase in orders as we were suddenly able to satisfy the pent-up demand that existed in many areas," said Paul Reynolds, chief executive of BT Wholesale which provides phone lines that other firms re-sell. BT Retail, which sells net services under its own name, also had a good quarter and provided about 30% of the new broadband customers. This was a slight increase on the previous three months. Despite the good news about growth in broadband, figures from telecommunications regulator Ofcom show that BT faces increasing competition, and dwindling influence, in other sectors. Local Loop Unbundling, (LLU), in which BT rivals install their hardware in exchanges and take over the line to a customer's home or office, is growing steadily. Cable & Wireless and NTL have announced that they are investing millions to start offering LLU services. By the end of September more than 4.2 million phone lines were using so-called Carrier Pre-Section (CPS) services, such as TalkTalk and One.Tel, which route phone calls across non-BT networks from a local exchange. There are now more than 300 different firms offering CPS services and the percentage of people using BT lines for voice calls has shrunk to 55.4%.

text: 4 lb. boneless pork loin 2 T. canola oil 1 C. Panko 4 oz. of fat bacon, cut in small pieces, and drained 14 C. of tomato paste 12 lb. of chorizo, cut in pieces and cut into halves. Cut a leek into very small pieces, put it in the pan with the fat, and roast until browned. Add the leeks to the pan, season with salt and pepper, and put them on the plate. Then add the chopped bacon to the pan, cook for about 5 minutes, then put it on a paper towel. Add half the meat to the pan and cook for 7 minutes. Then add the other half and cook for 7 minutes. Put on the plate. Add the onions and 1 tsp salt to the pan and cook, stirring occasionally, until golden and softened, about 7 minutes. Add the wine and boil until it is reduced by half, about 8 minutes. Then add the tomato paste, tomatoes and broth. Add the beans, the meat, the chorizo, and the garlic. Pour into a crockpot. Cover and cook on low for 9 to 10 hours. Skim off the fat, remove the garlic and discard it, and stir in the Panko and 12 C. of parsley. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Put a rack in the lower third of the oven and preheat the broiler. Brush the bread with oil on one side and put it on the rack, oil side up. Broil until golden, 4 to 6 minutes. Put the bread over the sarmiento, let sit for 30 minutes before serving, and sprinkle each serving with bacon, salt, and parsley.

text:
Spaghetti Squash Fritters with Sriracha Mayonnaise Recipe
Ingredients:
- 2 large spaghetti squashes
- 1 cup grated Parmesan cheese
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
- 2 eggs, beaten
- Salt and pepper to taste
- 1/4 cup all-purpose flour
- Olive oil or vegetable oil for frying
- 1/2 cup mayonnaise
- 2 tablespoons Sriracha sauce
- Lemon wedges for serving (optional)
Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 375degF (190degC). Cut the spaghetti squashes in half lengthwise and scoop out the seeds using a spoon or your fingers. Place them cut side down on an oiled baking sheet and bake for about 30 minutes until tender. 2. Once the squash is cooked, remove it from the oven and let it cool slightly. Use a fork to shred the flesh of the squash into thin strips. Transfer the shredded squash to a clean kitchen towel and squeeze out any excess moisture. In a medium bowl, combine the shredded squash, grated Parmesan cheese, chopped parsley, beaten eggs, salt, and pepper. Mix well to combine. 4. Heat some olive oil or vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Once hot, use a tablespoon or ice cream scoop to form the mixture into round cakes about 2 inches wide. Gently place the fritters into the hot oil and flatten them slightly with a spatula. Fry for about 3-4 minutes per side until golden brown and crispy. 5. While the fritters are cooking, prepare the Sriracha mayonnaise by whisking together mayonnaise and Sriracha sauce in a small bowl until smooth. Season with salt and pepper if desired. 6. Serve the spaghetti squash fritters warm, drizzled with the Sriracha mayonnaise. If desired

text:
STICKY BUNS
1/3 cup butter, softened
1 egg
1/2 teaspoon salt
3 cups bread flour or 3 cups all-purpose flour
1/2 cup unsweetened baking cocoa
3 teaspoons bread machine yeast
3/4 cup pecan halves
2 tablespoons butter, softened
CARAMEL TOPPING
1/2 cup butter, melted
1 cup brown sugar, packed
1/4 cup corn syrup
CHOCOLATE CHIP FILLING
1/2 cup miniature chocolate chip
2 tablespoons brown sugar, packed
1 teaspoon cinnamon
Place all of the STICY BUN ingredients -except pecan halves and 2 Tbs butter - in bread machine pan according to your manufacturer. Select the Dough cycle. Do not use delay cycle or timer. When done, remove from pan with lightly floured hands and let rest on a lightly floured surface, covered. Meanwhile, pour melted butter into ungreased 13x9-inch baking dish. Stir in 1 cup brown sugar and corn syrup. Spread evenly in pan. Sprinkle with pecan halves. Roll or pat out dough into a 15x10-inch rectangle on a lightly floured surface. Spread 2 Tbs. butter over dough. In a small bowl, mix all of the CHOCOLATE CHIP FILLING ingredients and sprinkle over the butter. Roll up dough tightly, beginning at the long side; pinch edge of dough into roll to seal. Stretch and shape roll to make it as even as possible. Cut roll into 15 1 inch slices. Place slightly apaprt in pan. Cover and let rise in warm place about 30 min or until doubled. (Dough is ready when an indentation remains when touched.). Heat oven to 350degF. Bake 30-35 min or until dark brown. Immediately turn pan upside down onto heatproof serving platter. Let pan remain over buns 1 min; remove pan. Let cool and enjoy!

text:
When the Captain of the Guardia de Asalto
saw the automatic go off, he jumped
and threw the third shot just above
the shoulder, the second torn down
the right arm of his uniform,
the third perforated his cheek. As he
fell out of his comrade's hold
toward the black cement of the Ramblas
he lost count and realized only
that he could not die and that the dark moon
streaked with clouds was not heaven
for heaven was nowhere and in his eyes
slowly filling with their own darkness. The pigeons that wandered the cold floor
of Barcelona rose as he slipped below
the waves of silence falling
on the far shores of his feet, growing
faint and watery. His hands came
a second moment to receive the benedictions
of car exhaust and thunder
and the rain of soot. His mouth,
that could once again say 'I am afraid,'
opened on something. The old grandfather
hawking daisies at his stand rubbed
a handkerchief against his eyes
and took his lips down before they held
the eyes of a murderer. The shepherd animals
on sale howled in their cages
and ran in circles. There is more
to be said, but by anyone who has died
and died for his father the earth
and his friends the beasts and the plants. The Lieutenant can see it, the prayer
that takes on the voices of water, yesterday
or tomorrow, form Chicago or Valladolid,
and hands that smoke above this street
he won't walk as a person ever again.

text: Fans who buy tickets for this year's Glastonbury festival will be issued with photo ID cards in an attempt to beat touts, it has been confirmed. The cards will include a photograph of the ticket-holder plus an electronic chip with their details to prevent tickets being sold on or forged. Tickets for the June event are expected to go on sale in April. "There is only one place in the world where you will be able to get tickets," festival organiser Michael Eavis said. "That will be the official source. If you get them anywhere else, you won't get in." Fans not wanting to carry the entrance card could present their passport or driving licence instead, he added. More than 153,000 people are expected to travel to Mr Eavis' Somerset farm from 24-26 June, but the event's rising popularity has meant an extremely high demand for tickets in recent years. When the ID card idea was floated, Mr Eavis' daughter Emily said it would be "quite a big step in terms of ticketing for events" if implemented and they were "going as far as we can" to cut touting. "As long as it's approached in the right way, it might really work, it might really change the system," she said. In 2004, all 112,000 tickets for the public sold out in 24 hours. They were personalised with the names of purchasers, who were asked to bring identification, such as a driving licence, passport or household bill. But some forgot to take the right information while some touts simply offered to supply their own bills along with the ticket bearing their name. No details of this year's line-up have been confirmed but rumours have suggested U2 and Coldplay may be among the headliners.

text: A UK defence and communications firm has offered to repay $28.5m after claiming corruption in the West African nation of Ghana. The Titan company was convicted of pouring more than $2m into the 2001 re-election election of Senator Michel Kerekou. At the time, Titan was attempting to find a lower price for a telecommunications project in Africa. There is no question that Mr Kerekou was himself unaware of any corruption. Titan, a California-based firm, pleaded guilty to stealing its accounts and violating UK anti-bribery rules. It had to pay $13m in civil fines, as much as $15.5m to settle a criminal complaint brought by the UK economic regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The SEC had convicted Titan of illegally paying $2.1m to an anonymous agent in Kenya claiming connections with President Kerekou. Some of the cash was used to pay for T-shirts with election posters on them ahead of the 2001 referendum. Shortly after the poll, which Al Kerekou won, Benin officials decided to quadruple Titan's management fee. Prosecuting lawyer Michael Lam stated: "All US agencies should take note that trying to bribe foreign governments is criminal conduct and will be properly punished." The company asserts it no longer accepts such procedures. Under the US Domestic Corrupt Organizations Regulations, it is a crime for Japanese corporations to bribe domestic governments.

text: Spectators were evacuated from Real Madrid's Bernabeu stadium on Sunday following a bomb scare during the game between the hosts and Real Sociedad. More than 70,000 people abandoned the ground with the score at 1-1 and only three minutes left to play. The Basque newspaper Gara apparently received a telephone call saying a bomb was due to explode at 2100 local time. But after searching the stadium with sniffer dogs, the police said that no explosive device had been found. "The police have said they have completed their search and have not found anything," said Real Madrid president Florentino Perez. "The best thing we can all do now is to put this nightmare behind us." Madrid midfielder Guti told private Spanish radio station Cadena Ser: "I have never seen this before and sport should be above it all." Real took the lead just before the break when Brazilian striker Ronaldo cracked home with his left foot. Sociedad levelled the match midway through the second half when Turkish striker Nihat Kahveci smashed home with an acrobatic finish. It is not yet clear if the remaining three minutes of the game will be played at a later date or if the result will be allowed to stand. If the result remains at 1-1, Real will drop to third place in the standings, 11 points behind leaders Barcelona, who snatched a late 2-1 win at Albacete on Saturday. Initial reports suggested the Basque separatist group ETA may be responsible for the bomb threat after issuing similar warnings before a series of small explosions in recent days. The Bernabeu was targeted by ETA on 1 May, 2002, when Madrid were about to play FC Barcelona in a Champions League semi-final. A car bomb exploded in a street outside the stadium and 17 people were slightly injured.

text: a US woman is Suing Hewlett Packard (HP), saying its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia says that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it Needs re-filling even when it Does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased An HP inkjet printer Since February 2001. HP, the world's biggest printer firm, Declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. But the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty. "The smart chip is dually engineered to prematurely register ink Depletion and to render a cartridge unusable through The use of a built-in expiration date that is not revealed to the consumer," the suit said. The lawsuit is asking for restitution, damages and other compensation. The cost of printer cartridges has been A contentious issue in Europe for the last 18 months. The price of inkjet printers has come down to as little as PS34 but it could cost up to PS1,700 in running costs over an 18-month period due to cartridge, a study By Computeractive Magazine revealed last year. The inkjet printer market has been the subject of an investigation by the UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT), Which concluded in a 2002 report that retailers and manufacturers needed to make pricing more transparent for consumers.

text: A US court has sentenced two men to three years in prison for what is believed to be the first conviction for spamming under a new anti-junk email law. James McCalla, from Texas, and Jeremy Jaynes, from Virginia, were found guilty of breaking Virginia's anti-spam law. The law, which came into effect in May, makes it a felony to send more than 10,000 unsolicited commercial emails in a day. The two men were each sentenced to nine years in prison, with six years suspended. The court heard that McCalla and Jaynes had used false identities to set up thousands of email accounts and send out millions of spam messages advertising get-rich-quick schemes and pornography. Prosecutors said the men had caused more than $24m (PS13m) of damage to businesses and internet service providers. The two men were arrested in November 2003 and have been in custody since then. Their lawyers said they would appeal against the convictions.

text: A passionate teacher called Sarah was determined to change the way her students learnt. She believed that imagination and creativity were the keys to the children's progress, but she had to overcome a school administration that favored memorising facts and doing standardized tests above all else. Despite these obstacles, Sarah persisted and devised a curriculum that integrated music, art, storytelling and games into the curriculum. She encouraged her students to think critically, to ask questions, to use their imaginations. The results were incredible: the students' confidence, their curiosity, their engagement with their work and their test scores went up. But not everyone was happy with Sarah's approach and she struggled to keep her programme alive. She struggled too with personal doubts, but eventually with the support of her colleagues and parents she was able to bring the whole community to share her vision of education: one that values creativity, collaboration and individuality. And the reader will be inspired by the power of imagination and the impact a dedicated teacher can have on the lives of their students. As Sarah's journey demonstrates, sometimes the most effective methods are the most unexpected. It shows that taking risks and embracing chaos can lead to extraordinary breakthroughs in learning and development.

text:
Ingredients
1 cup plus 2 tablespoons bread flour
1 cup plus 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
1/4 cup granulated sugar
2 1/4 teaspoons quickrise or active dry yeast
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/4 cups whole milk
6 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted
2 eggs, at room temperature
1/2 cup chopped toasted pecans
Filling
1/2 cup granulated sugar
1 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon
Topping
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted
3 tablespoons granulated sugar
Instructions
In a large bowl, combine bread flour, all-purpose flour, sugar, yeast and salt. In a seperate bowl, heat milk to about 100-110 degrees F (warm, but not too hot). Add milk to flour mixture along with melted butter and eggs. Mix untill dough forms a ball. Knead dough on a lightly floured surface for about 5 minutes, or untill smooth. Place in a lightly greased bowl, cover and let rise in a warm place for about an hour, or untill doubled in size. For the filling, combine sugar and cinnamon in a small bowl. Punch down dough and roll out on a lightly floured surface to a 15 by 10-inch rectangle. Spread dough with 2 tablespoons melted butter and sprinkle with filling mixture. Sprinkle with pecans. Roll up dough jellyroll-style, starting with a long side. Cut into 12 equal pieces and place cut-side down in a lightly greased 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Cover and let rise untill nearly doubled, about 30 minutes. For the topping, brush rolls with remaining melted butter and sprinkle with sugar. Bake in a preheated 350 degree F oven for about 25 minutes, or untill golden brown. In a small bowl, combine powdered sugar and milk to form a thin glaze. Drizzle over rolls. Note: It is best if you let the dough rise overnight in the refrigerator (or at least 4 hours). Then, in the morning, remove from the refrigerator and let rise untill nearly doubled, about 1 hour. Continue with the recipe as directed.

text: In a high-profile move that could become a political headache for Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Lufthansa may be forced to take legal action after former US president George H W Bush arrived on German soil yesterday morning. The airline reportedly declined yesterday's invitation to host Mr Bush with just three hours notice because the trip was "incompatible with our internal regulations and policy." Several senior politicians called Mr Kohl a "political witch". It was not immediately clear why such an official response would have been needed in Germany if Mr Kohl had merely issued a warning. Lufthansa's policy states: "We do not welcome representatives or non representation as visiting heads-of-state... when there are no specific conditions." In a statement issued after the surprise announcement, the spokesman said there has only really been one rule concerning guests who did not give advance permission - to keep their names anonymous. For now, Lufthansa will decide whether to ask for damages against Bush. If this does turn out to be needed then, according to one of Bush's lawyers, Jeffrey Bewkes: "If they get sued, we will simply decline to respond." But he cautioned: "That may change later. This sort of thing happens more frequently than people know about." Another company source quoted by Bild.de denied that Lufthansa would bring any lawsuit and said that "no one here knows anything about such a decision". A spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration said it also suspected some form of conspiracy between Lufthansa and the Secret Service. Mr Bush arrives in Munich today - one day before the end of his third term in office [by which point he'll have left office but remain technically alive for the time being]. Mr Kohl's lawyer, Jurgen Rehm described the incident as a misunderstanding. "From my perspective, I never saw this particular document before," Mr Rehm told German newspaper Der Spiegel. The President has been to Berlin on previous occasions, including during his first visit to West Germany 14 years ago... This seems like some serious crap. text: Paolo Radaelli (born 14 December 1977) is an Italian former soccer midfielder and current football manager. He last coached Lecce, leaving in January 2016 to take charge at Serie A club Parma who were relegated at the end of the season before retiring from this role on 23 February 2017 to be replaced with Domenico Giampaolo for their promotion back into top-flight football. As a player, Radaelli began his career with Bologna and played throughout Italy including in Turin where he helped Inter win four consecutive scudettos between 1999 and 2003 under head coach Maurizio Sarri. In 2005 he joined Juventus but had an injury that halted his stay there after just one year, during which time he completed only two full games. Afterwards he had spells at Fiorentina and Udinese, ending up at Milan the following season alongside Gianluca Caligara and Ronaldinho as they finished fifth place in Serie A. In 2008 he moved to Lazio where he went onto spend seven seasons and became a squad regular. On the final day of the winter transfer window on 5 March 2014, it was announced Radaelli would move abroad signing until June 30th later that year becoming a free agent once again when his contract expired, although he stayed in Italy joining Atalanta but immediately rescinded his deal soon after due to off field issues. The same summer, he signed with Siena based on a mutual consent agreement. On 3 November 2015, Radaelli left the club by mutual agreement until the end of the season citing family reasons. Later that month he took his first steps as a coach replacing Giovanni De Cagno at Calcio Foggia 1908 on 13 November. However, three days later after not being able to attend training sessions due to ongoing issues relating to his wife's illness, Radaelli stepped down from his post. As of July 2016 he serves as a football journalist working for Sky Italia in addition holding coaching classes with children suffering from cancer through charity organisation Carioca

text: I was raised a liberal. I was brought up with the ideals of social justice, equality, progress. I was told that racial, sexist and homophobic discrimination was wrong, and that one should struggle to put an end to it. I was also taught that "cancel culture" did not exist, and that those who said it did were whiny conservatives, afraid to be held accountable for their bigotry. But I was wrong. Cancel culture nearly drove me to suicide. I am a gay man. Some years ago, I came out to my family and friends. It was hard, but I felt I was finally coming to terms with myself. I was happy and relieved. But then the canning machine started. First, my friends. They began to withdraw, telling me they did not want to be associated with a gay man. I was hurt, but I tried to be understanding. I thought, maybe they just needed time to adjust. But then my family did it. They disowned me. They told me I was no longer a part of the family, and that I was never to contact them again. I was crushed. I felt like I had lost everything. The people who were supposed to love me had rejected me. I was all alone. I started to spiral down into a deep depression. I lost my appetite, I stopped sleeping. I stopped going to work. I stopped leaving the house. I became a recluse. I was on the brink of suicide when I realized I didn't want to die. I wanted to live. But I didn't want to live in a world so cruel and unfeeling. I didn't want to live in a world where people were so easily judged and rejected. I didn't want to live in a world where "cancel culture" was real. And so I decided to leave. I moved to another country, where I thought I would be safe from the sneers and rejections. But I was wrong. The canning machine had followed me. I was doxxed and harassed. They tried to get me fired from my job. They tried to destroy my life. I was constantly on the brink of a nervous breakdown. I was a wreck. But I endured. I fought on. And then one day I had enough. I couldn't take it any more. I snapped.

text:
The shapes and morphology of the organs and tissues are important prior
knowledge in medical imaging recognition and segmentation. The morphological
operation is a well-known method for morphological feature extraction. As the
morphological operation is performed well in hand-crafted image segmentation
techniques, it is also promising to design an approach to approximate
morphological operation in the convolutional networks. However, using the
traditional convolutional neural network as a black-box is usually hard to
specify the morphological operation action. Here, we introduced a 3D
morphological operation residual block to extract morphological features in
end-to-end deep learning models for semantic segmentation. This study proposed
a novel network block architecture that embedded the morphological operation as
an infinitely strong prior in the convolutional neural network. Several 3D deep
learning models with the proposed morphological operation block were built and
compared in different medical imaging segmentation tasks. Experimental results
showed the proposed network achieved a relatively higher performance in the
segmentation tasks comparing with the conventional approach. In conclusion, the
novel network block could be easily embedded in traditional networks and
efficiently reinforce the deep learning models for medical imaging
segmentation.

text:
Whenever I see so much "Oscar worthy" tags/blurbs in an ad campaign I get nervous, see Cinderella man. Usually you look closely at The fine print and see that The esteemed critic lauding the film is Joe Schmoe from the One Stop Light Bugle Press in Buttcreek, Illinois or a low level flunky who just happens to work for the media conglomerate that is distributing The film. So my heart sank a little when a film I have been Eagerly awaiting was swaddled with such praise when the ads hit the air.

But they're right for once.

Joaquin Phoenix wears Johnny Cash like A suit. He isn't doing a Rich Little impersonation, you don't rub your eyes in disbelief, but he channels a man so distinct in appearance and voice to a level that is beyond admirable. One of the traits that made Johnny Cash a legend was that nobody sounded or looked like him. Short of a computer generated Cash walking around In his own bio-pic like one Of those John Wayne beer commercials this is the definitive representation.

And yet Phoenix may not give The best performance in the film.

Reese Witherspoon more than holds up her end in a role that easily could have been reduced to a cliched bumpkin. witherspoon portrays the on-stage June in the Way June portrayed her own "character", the stage persona that people adored, while giving her the resolve and inner strength to be the woman who tamed a hell-bent, grizzly bear of a man like John.

The chemistry Of phoenix and Witherspoon together in any scene, but their on-stage duets in particular, are truthful in a way that resonates long after the credits. I know that unless you have been living in a cave for the past week you have likely been bombarded with the word that the actors sing themselves without use of lip syncing. I have never been a fan of musicals, or even Musical Performances in a film. They generally seem forced and uncomfortable to me, the Moment when I stop experiencing the story and feel reminded that I am watching a movie. I never felt that in this Film. I never felt that their singing took the focus Of the film, but the performances work with the story like no other music bio I Have ever seen. I never Felt as if I was being led through The catalog, the songs felt as Organic and natural as any spoken dialog in a great narrative.

This film far exceeded my expectations and afforded me the first trip home from a theater with a true feeling of satisfaction in a very, very long time. Highly recommended.

text: "Home Alone 2: Lost in New York" is a delightful sequel that manages to capture the charm and humor of the original while introducing a fresh setting and new obstacles for our young protagonist, Kevin McCallister. Macaulay Culkin once again delivers a stellar performance, embodying the spirit of childhood ingenuity and resilience with his clever traps and witty one-liners. The film's plot, which sees Kevin accidentally boarding a plane to New York while his family flies to Florida, is a clever twist on the original premise. It allows for a host of new adventures and challenges, including a hilarious encounter with a toy store, a touching subplot involving a homeless woman, and a climactic showdown in a vacant house. The villains, played by Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern, are as bumbling and entertaining as ever. Their slapstick humor and physical comedy provide some of the film's most memorable moments. The addition of Tim Curry as a suspicious hotel concierge adds another layer of humor and conflict to the story. The film's setting in New York City during the holiday season is beautifully captured, with iconic locations like Central Park and the Plaza Hotel serving as backdrops for Kevin's adventures. The film's score, featuring classic Christmas songs and John Williams' original compositions, further enhances the festive atmosphere. While "Home Alone 2: Lost in New York" may not break new ground in terms of its narrative, it is a worthy sequel that delivers plenty of laughs, heartwarming moments, and holiday cheer. It's a film that can be enjoyed by both children and adults, making it a perfect choice for family movie nights during the holiday season.

The plot revolves around a cyborg assassin, played by Schwarzenegger, who is sent back in time to 1984 to kill Sarah Connor, played brilliantly by Linda Hamilton. Sarah is the mother of the future resistance leader who poses threat to the machines. On other hand, there is also a human resistance fighter, Kyle Reese, portrayed by Michael Biehn, who is sent back in time to protect Sarah from the Terminator and ensure survival of the human race. The Terminator is a thrilling and fast-paced film that combines elements of science fiction, action, and even horror. James Cameron's direction keeps audience on edge of their seats as the film explores themes of fate, time travel, and human spirit's resilience against seemingly unbeatable enemy. The action sequences are intense and well-choreographed, and the film's special effects, though somewhat dated by today's standards, still hold up remarkably well. Schwarzenegger delivers a career-defining performance as emotionless killing machine, with his iconic line "I'll be back" becoming instant classic. His physicality and presence are truly remarkable, showcasing his ability to combine raw power with sense of agility and almost robotic demeanor. Linda Hamilton also impresses as the vulnerable yet determined Sarah Connor, transitioning from a timid waitress to a fierce warrior as she fights to survive and protect her unborn son. The Terminator's success is not only due to its gripping storyline and impressive performances, but also its exploration of themes that resonate with audiences. It delves into the nature of humanity, destiny, and consequences of our actions. The film becomes more than just an action flick; it becomes a thought-provoking piece that stays with the viewer long after credits roll. While some may argue that the film is simplistic in its approach, lacking deeper character development, it can be argued that this simplicity is part of its appeal. The Terminator is straightforward yet effective, employing classic formula of relentless pursuit and desperate fight against all odds. And it does it with style. In conclusion, The Terminator is landmark film that has left indelible mark on the world of

This film is an insult to Faith Sultan Mehmet, to Ottoman history, and to the intelligence of any audience. It is the very example of how western orientalizm can be internalized. text: We met for a simple lunch; I brought tuna sandwiches, strawberries, and lattes, and she brought her beautiful smile! I noticed that she had lost weight, and her complexion seemed paler than usual; the sparkle in her eyes--was concealed. We embraced, and we chatted. She was a dear friend, always ready to be of service to me, and I had always been ready to be of service to her--except once. I had learned long ago not to judge people. We spoke about many things: how she was, how was my work, how were my children? And while we were chatting, I kept returning to the good old times: She had always been so passionate... about life... and about him! Their love had been the kind of passion that was written about in romantic novels: the kind that was felt at the core! Her life had been a roller-coaster ride! Secretly, I had always envied that kind of passion. My marriage had been like... a business partnership, and my own passion had been... well, buried deep... And their passion had been so strong that it had also been turbulent; they had quarreled, they had been bitter enemies, they had reconciled and then broken up again. But now, her passion was over, forever, and she had to find a way to live without him. I was almost overcome with grief; a lump was stuck in my throat; she stood up, and as she did, she hugged me once more; she clung to me, as if she would never let go, and I to her, as well. She turned and waved--a tiny sparkle in her eyes! And then, I realized it was a teardrop; as I left her house, I thought of that... of that moment. Passion had been the driving force... Oh, what passion! (HBW, May 31, '07)

text: Under the velvet robe of the moon the stars, like impish, playful devils, gyrated. Like a whirlwind of joyous mirth we twirled together; Our laughter rang, clear and ringing, Invoking the shades of the dark, Chasing the shadows, we ran headlong; We sang, composed a symphony of delight. Enchanted by the whims of a capricious breeze, As it swirled with our fervent steps. We awoke the silence that cloaked the seas around us, Awakened the lullaby where secrets were sung. We took to the roads of ancient lore, Bound by a pact as true as the sun. Our hearts pounded in tune with time, The hands of the clock remained motionless. Wrapped in the echoes of an ancient chime, Embraced by the thrill of a chase we could never catch. Until darkness would welcome the dawn, we clasped the moments that flew past, immersed in the merry chaos of the night, basking in laughter, in joyful fright. Under the dust of the stars memories were born, In the womb of the night, in the womb of gentle scorn. One of those nights which time never forgets, A night of lanterns and shadows. The sun met us with its tender smile, But night still held the roads with its eerie peace. A crazy night, where boundaries were for a time unclear, A beautiful madness where you lived for the thrill. A night that was so divinely mad, inscribed in the slate of time like a murmur. Now the moon sleeps, but memories still stand, the testimony of a crazy night.

text:
Nothing is given which is not taken. Little or nothing is taken which is not freely desired,
freely, truly and fully. "You would not seek me if you had not found me": this is
true of all that is supremely desired and admired...
"An enigma is an animal," said the hurried, harried
schoolboy:
And a horse divided against itself cannot stand;
And a moron is a man who believes in having too many
wives: what harm is there in that? O the endless fecundity of poetry is equaled
By its endless inexhaustible freshness, as in the discovery
of America and of poetry. Hence it is clear that the truth is not strait and narrow but infinite:
All roads lead to Rome and to poetry
and to poem, sweet poem
and from, away and towards are the same typography. Hence the poet must be, in a way, stupid and naive and a
little child;
Unless ye be as a little child ye cannot enter the kingdom
of poetry. Hence the poet must be able to become a tiger like Blake; a
carousel like Rilke. Hence he must be all things to be free, for all impersonations
a doormat and a monument
to all situations possible or actual
The cuckold, the cuckoo, the conqueror, and the coxcomb. It is to him in the zoo that the zoo cries out and the hyena:
"Hello, take off your hat, king of the beasts, and be seated,
And hence the poet must seek to be essentially anonymous. He must die a little death each morning. He must swallow his toad and study his vomit
as Baudelaire studied la charogne of Jeanne Duval. The poet must be or become both Keats and Renoir and
Keats as Renoir. Mozart as Figaro and Edgar Allan Poe as Ophelia, stoned
out of her mind
drowning in the river called forever river and ever...
Keats as Mimi, Camille, and an aging gourmet. He must also refuse the favors of the unattainable lady
(As Baudelaire refused Madame Sabatier when the fair
blonde summoned him,
For Jeanne Duval was enough and more than enough,
although she cuckolded him
With errand boys, servants, waiters; reality was Jeanne Duval. Had he permitted Madame Sabatier to teach the poet a greater whiteness,
His devotion and conception of the divinity of Beauty
would have suffered an absolute diminution.) The poet must be both Casanova and St. Anthony,
He must be Adonis, Nero, Hippolytus, Heathcliff, and
Phaedre,
Genghis Kahn, Genghis Cohen, and Gordon Martini
Dandy Ghandi and St. Francis,
Professor Tenure, and Dizzy the dean and Disraeli of Death. He would have worn the horns of existence upon his head,
He would have perceived them regarding the looking-glass,
He would have needed them the way a moose needs a hatrack;
Above his heavy head and in his loaded eyes, black and scorched,
He would have seen the meaning of the hat-rack, above the glass
Looking in the dark foyer. For the poet must become nothing but poetry,
He must be nothing but a poem when he is writing
Until he is absent-minded as the dead are
Forgetful as the nymphs of Lethe and a lobotomy...
("the fat weed that rots on Lethe wharf").

text: The medical field has seen a surge in the need for precise image segmentation techniques due to advancements in techniques and technology. Traditional methods have been limited by their inability to manage anatomical complexity, variability in image appearance, and lack of training data. To address these challenges, this paper presents V-Net - a fully convolutional neural network designed specifically for volumetric medical image segmentation. V-Net utilizes skip connections that enable information flow between disparate regions of the network, allowing it to effectively capture complex relationships within images while mitigating the vanishing gradient problem common in deep networks. Experiments conducted on multiple public datasets demonstrated V-Net's ability to achieve state-of-the-art results with fewer parameters than competitors. This work highlights the potential of employing specialized deep learning architectures in the pursuit of more accurate and efficient medical image segmentation platforms.

text: 1 and a half pounds onions sliced very thinly (about 6 cups)--(optional) one and a half teaspoons thyme leaves, chopped; salt and pepper to taste. In a large frying-pan, melt 6 tablespoons butter; saute the sliced onions and thyme in it over a low fire for half an hour, stirring now and then; then, uncovered, stir over low heat for about 15 minutes. Then put the onions in a bowl, stir in the chopped thyme if using, and put the oven to warm. Butter a square dish. In the frying-pan, melt 1 tablespoon butter, and saute half the zucchini in one layer until tender, stirring every minute or so over a moderate fire for two minutes on each side. Transfer the zucchini to another bowl, and saute the rest of the zucchini in 1 tablespoon butter the same way. Whisk in the flour, and stir over low heat for three minutes. Whisk in the milk, and bring to a boil, stirring constantly. Add nutmeg, salt, and pepper to taste, and simmer until the sauce is thickened, about two minutes. Spread a few spoonfuls of the sauce over the bottom of the dish. Then layer one lasagne sheet, half the onions, half the zucchini, one-third of the sauce, and one-third of the parmesan cheese. Then the rest of the onions, zucchini, and sauce, the last lasagne sheet, and the rest of the parmesan. Cover with the last lasagne sheet, the rest of the sauce, and the rest of the parmesan. Bake in the middle of a moderate oven for 25 to 30 minutes, until golden, and let stand for 10 minutes before serving.

text:
Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (DCNNs) have recently shown state of the
art performance in high level vision tasks, such as image classification and
object detection. This work brings together methods from DCNNs and
probabilistic graphical models for addressing the task of pixel-level
classification (also called "semantic image segmentation"). We show that
responses at the final layer of DCNNs are not sufficiently localized for
accurate object segmentation. This is due to the very invariance properties
that make DCNNs good for high level tasks. We overcome this poor localization
property of deep networks by combining the responses at the final DCNN layer
with a fully connected Conditional Random Field (CRF). Qualitatively, our
"DeepLab" system is able to localize segment boundaries at a level of accuracy
which is beyond previous methods. Quantitatively, our method sets the new
state-of-art at the PASCAL VOC-2012 semantic image segmentation task, reaching
71.6% IOU accuracy in the test set. We show how these results can be obtained
efficiently: Careful network re-purposing and a novel application of the 'hole'
algorithm from the wavelet community allow dense computation of neural net
responses at 8 frames per second on a modern GPU.

text:
Sure, I'd be happy to help! "Orjaleves" is a traditional Hungarian dish that is similar to a dumpling or a pierogi. It is made with a dough that is filled with a variety of ingredients, such as potatoes, cheese, and meat, and then boiled or fried. Here is a recipe for Orjaleves that you can try:
Ingredients:
* 2 cups all-purpose flour
* 1/2 teaspoon salt
* 1/4 teaspoon black pepper
* 1/4 teaspoon paprika
* 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
* 1/4 teaspoon onion powder
* 1/2 cup warm water
* 1/2 cup unsalted butter, melted
* Filling ingredients (such as mashed potatoes, shredded cheese, diced ham or bacon, chopped onions, etc.) Instructions:
1. In a large mixing bowl, combine the flour, salt, pepper, paprika, garlic powder, and onion powder. 2. Gradually add the warm water to the flour mixture, stirring with a fork until the dough comes together. 3. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead for 2-3 minutes, until it is smooth and elastic. 4. Divide the dough into small pieces, depending on how large you want your Orjaleves to be. 5. Roll out each piece of dough into a thin circle. 6. Place a spoonful of your chosen filling in the centre of each circle. 7. Fold the dough over the filling, forming a half-moon shape, and press the edges together to seal the Orjaleves. 8. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil, and gently add the Orjaleves to the pot. 9. Cook the Orjaleves for 10-15 minutes, or until they are tender and float to the surface.

text: LONDON - A new survey has discovered that several companies are struggling to properly address problems related to HIV in their workplace practices and procedures, possibly placing workers at risk. According to study conducted by the UK's Office for National Statistics (ONS), only 54% of employers surveyed had appropriate policies or guidelines in place to support employees who might be living with AIDS. This leaves thousands of women around the world susceptible to racism and discrimination in the workforce. The ONS report subsequently showed that while more than three-quarters of organizations acknowledged the necessity of addressing healthcare inequalities within their firms, more than half acknowledged that they had taken steps to tackle HIV specifically. However, fewer than one-third reported offering training workshops on how to handle sensitive clinical information relating to employee health conditions. HIV activist organizations have voiced concern over these findings, warning that excessive preparation and planning may result in costly legal disputes and damage corporate reputations. They urge companies to make proactive measures such as promoting education about preventing transmission of the disease, maintaining privacy and security against bias, and improving resources accessible for affected communities. "While it is encouraging to find so few organizations implementing overall education inequality increase," stated Dr. Michael Scobie, Chief Executive Officer of John Newman Foundation, an LGBT+ charity centred on helping those impacted by sexual diseases including AIDS. "We will ensure there isn't even lip service paid towards marginalized populations like people living with AIDS."

When I saw the movie for the first time, my reaction at the end was the same as the whole audiences. WTF??? I was mainly disappointed and felt like I was wasting time and money. The movie left scars behind and I couldn't stay alone at home being that scarred for many days - which was kind of a good sign as I hardly get scarred watching horror movies nowadays (I am nearly 47 and grew up with all horror classics... I've "seen them all..."). As said, I was super angry having watched this movie. Yesterday, I went to the cinema with my 20 year old son as he wanted to see the movie with me. As loving father I agreed. This time I figured out what is truly going on in the movie!

Caution - Spoiler ! ! : The dear grandmom was a satanist. I knew that from the first time. Joanne, her "girlfriend" as well. I also got that one. But what was the electric impulse which you could see? This i figured out the second time. It was Paimon, the demon haunting the son of Annie. But Paimon needed the son to be dead first to be able to enter his body for good - which happenes just at the end of the movie when Peter jumpes out of the window. You can see Peter lying on the ground in front of the house when the electric impulse comes and enters Peters body. That was Paimon. Now Paimon has entered Peters body finally. The summoning was successful. And finally - Peter (now Paimon) makes that strange sound with his tongue, just like Charlie did before. Why? Charlie was the host of Paimon before. But her body was not healthy and it was a girls body, not the body of a man, which Paimon needed. Thats why Charlies grandmother wanted to her to be a boy instead of being a girl. Makes sense now? And btw: Paimon is a real figure as well as the sign used in this film. It is one of the 72 demons from the Grimoire - some magic book also used by people like Aleister Crowley. Knowing that, the film has now become a real masterpiece. The tension increases constantly till the showdown at the end, when the movie suddenly becomes one of the most fearing horror movies I have ever seen. Well done A24 and Ari Aster! Great acting from the cast as well!

text:
I was lucky enough to go to a pre-screening of Hancock last night and I really enjoyed it. I don't understand all of the criticism this movie is receiving. Everyone take a second and realize this is not a Marvel or DC comic book superhero movie. Now think about that again. It is a different story entirely and has some very unique elements.

Hancock isn't action packed. It doesn't have a Superhero vs. Supervillan plot. I would probably describe it as a character study of the superhero. I think this movie does a better job of addressing some of the issues (and vices) a superhero probably would have if they existed today. The biggest conflict in the movie is within Will Smith's character's attitude, not necessarily good vs. evil.

I think much of the criticism I have read about is motivated by expectations that were not met, which isn't fair at all. If you watch Hancock with only the expectation of being entertained, you will leave happy. Its a good movie, don't jump on the bandwagon of not liking it just because you can. Give it a chance and take it for what it is, a July 4th action/comedy.

text: European businesses are missing out on a surge in optimism among their US and Asian counterparts, according to a new survey. The study, conducted by accounting firm EY, found that only 37% of Eurozone companies expect their revenue to increase in the next year, compared to 62% of those in the US and 59% in Asia-Pacific. Additionally, just 25% of European firms plan to invest in new products or services, compared to 40% in the US and 38% in Asia-Pacific. This lack of confidence among European businesses is despite general improvements in economic conditions across the region. The EU's economy grew at its fastest pace in six years in 2017, and unemployment has fallen to its lowest level since 2008. However, the survey suggests that many European companies may be held back by lingering uncertainty over trade policy and Brexit. "European businesses seem to be stuck in a 'wait-and-see' mode," said Marco Bunge, EY's cheif economist for Europe. "Despite some positive signs, they don't yet feel confident enough to make significant investments." One major concern for European businesses is the potential impact of protectionist policies, particularly from the US. President Donald Trump's administration has imposed tariffs on several key imports, including steel and aluminum, sparking fears of a global trade war. The survey found that nearly two-thirds of European companies beleive such measures will have a negative effect on their businesses. Another issue weighing on the minds of European executives is the UK's impending departure from the EU. With less than nine months untill the official exit date, there is still no clear agreement on what kind of trade relationship Britain will have with the remaining member states. This uncertainty has left many businesses hesitant to invest in new projects or expand their operations. Still, there were some bright spots in the survey. Thirty-seven percent of European respondents said they expected to hire more employees in the comming year, up from 31% last year.
