text: ----O dwellers of the great cities, what is it that you come to see? This public earth, this public sky, this free river! As cheerfully as these bamboo flowers open at the gate, as sweetly as these wild birds sing in the forest. You see common flowering, the ripple of the river, the beauty of June everywhere; the old hawkswood oaks are bared, like old kings, in the wind, and the shade of the old pines echoes the song of the Mistress of Deer Island. This is where the artichoke grows, this is where the Curson Mill is; and between the river and the hill, the valley is a wonderful sight. You know well these edges of blossom, the swaying hillside, and the sun's flaming tips of the pine needles. And like some recollected psalm, like a sweet familiar face, not less because they are commonplace, do you love this day and this place? Not for nothing does the mind relax in the gentle air, and not for nothing does the brain rest from its daily toil. The lust of power, the greed of the heart, occupy the whole year; the demons who haunt us let us have this day of beauty. Unheard the paper boy, put aside the account book, the world will continue to turn in its circle, though we fall off today. The truants of life's weary school, with no plea from frugality, we change the money of our labors for God's gift. From the silent rooms, from the silent books, from the crowds of the streetcar and the city, we rest our tired heads on the bosom of Mother Earth. Summer's cool wind, on our fevered brows, the blue river through the green of the clustering pines, quenches our eyes, which have seen too much. For us these pleasant wooded ways are full of old memories, have felt the touch of a friendly hand, and heard the tale of love. A sacred presence abides over the earth where we meet, and these winding forest ways are trod by more than mortal feet. Our old friends, summoned from us by the voice Which they alone could hear, are coming from mystery to mystery, from life to life. We take each other's hands closer because of them, our voices are sweeter because of them. Our joy is theirs, their confidence is ours; alike above, below, here or there, the arms of one great love embrace us! 's current. Today we demand no password from the woods; what cares it for the fashionable cliche? The laughing waters drown the sounds of the town's jargon. And here the frown's sad, heavy countenance; The good-natured air and sunshine, They scorn the bigot's zeal. The load of male pride falls from our tired shoulders, the burden of egoism, and woman acts as the flowers and the birds. We have the freedom of the happy forest, the freedom of the brook; we have the freedom of the unshy wind amidst the cheerful flowers. "But here the evil thought finds no place, and the profane foot finds no way; Our grove, like Samothrace, is set apart from sin. We walk on sacred ground; Above, a sky more holy smiles; the songs of the Beatitudes ring through the leafy alleys. Let us give thanks to the good Providence that brings us back, for memories of good things past, for hopes of good things to come. If, unknown to us, there are other June days like these, if the laurels clad the river-sides in their green, And other feet tread these emerald ways, May the pilgrims, like us, come each year to feast on the flowery days, Then, O may the housewife be a young maid again, The bearded one a boy, And we, in heaven's eternal June, Glad of earthly joy!"

text:
Internet "file-sharers" are preparing to launch a new music-sharing network after another site was shut down by court order. A group of computer experts called Swarmix is developing Swarm, intended to allow people to share files over the internet without breaking the law. They say technology will mean files cannot be saved on individual computers, so the new service will not breach laws on copyright infringement. The new service will be run using computer network called Peerio. It will use encrypted data, similar to BitTorrent system, to ensure copyright-protected files are not stored on individual computers. Torrents work by splitting large files into many pieces. Sharing
The idea behind the Peerio network is to split files into hundreds of thousands of pieces and allow "snatches" of files to be transferred between computers rather than entire work. "Peerio is secure, distributed network," said Swarm spokeswoman Anna Sourine. "It is completely non-hierarchical and there is no central server. "Files are split into many, many pieces using encryption. "So they are not on computers but moving encrypted snatches of content over Peerio. "Every swarm on Peerio is completely independent and the technology will prevent a complete file from being downloaded. "All content is completely invisible to every user outside that particular swarm, as are identities of users in that swarm." Ms Sourine also denied that files could still be saved illegally on individual computers using method called ripping, which converts music into a separate file type that can be saved on a computer. She told BBC News: "We've not invented Peerio, it is a new development - we've just repurposed it to allow lawful swarming." Peerio was first developed as way of allowing anonymous, encrypted transfer of sensitive information. Swarmix has made agreements with several top music labels who feel that Peerio technology can be used for legitimate file sharing. These agreements have been kept anonymous as many labels are worried about public response to the new development.

text:
This film isn't for all people. That's to say about a lot of movies in general of course, but this one in particular brings up a big clashing point between critics; What do we want to see in our movies? What is more important, to portray a fictional setting for the sake of giving people a mind blowing visual experience or to amuse and amaze them with clever plot twists and intelligent dialogues?

First lets analyse what exactly this film is made of. Basically, the whole thing is just one epic fighting scene after another. Most noticeably is the camera work and the visual effects. Every shot seems like it was intended to be a work of art. The colours, the characters, the costumes, the backgrounds... every little detail has been given so much attention. During the big fights you'll also instantly notice the unique editing. There are a lot of "time slowdowns" throughout the battles which show what exactly is happening. Fatal wounds that slowly leak blood spatters in the air, decapitated heads travelling in slow-motion across the screen... it's all there.

The story on the other hand isn't very complicated, in the sense that the whole movie could probably be described in a sentence or two. The dialogues are simple and most often talk about moral values like freedom and honour. If you would look at the script, it would probably look like another movie that has nothing more to offer then idealistic visions of how life should be.

Reviewers of this title seem to be split up in two groups. They either love it with passion calling it an epic movie of the 21th century, or hate it even more and throw it off like a piece of garbage consisting of mindless action and silly cliche phrases. I feel reluctant to take a position in this argument. Normally it's tolerable to weigh out both sides of this matter to result in a fair judgement about a movie. Not in this one. On the one hand the visual are surely among the best to be witnessed in a movie. Every detail, every background, every special effect set to the scenes are so mindblowingly stunning. On the other hand the plot and dialogues are of the most simplistic and quite frankly dumb kind. "I fight for freedom! I'd rather die in honour then live in shame!" Sounds familiar?

Of course it could be debated that this movie was never intended in the first place to have a unique plot that makes your head spin. But from an objective point of view it's still lacking in this department, so it should be noted.

Now that's fine and all, but does that all make of the film? Is it worth watching or what? I think it is. For me the good outweighs the bad by miles. From the second the movie started it grabbed me and didn't let go. Every battle, every scene of the movie had me at the tip of my chair. Everything from the strong acting to the wondrous visuals to the war-shouts of the soldiers was just so stunning... it was truly a wonderful experience.

I did not one single moment felt like the movie lacked anything. But I could imagine why other people did.

So here's the deal.

If you are easily impressed by beautiful landscapes, wonderful camera-work and editing and powerful acting then go see this. Right. Now. You'll be missing out if you don't. There is so much to see, so much power in the way this comic is translated to the big screen... It'll leave you in awe.

However, you are looking for a good story, clever plot twists, some innovating to the world of the movies then skip this. 300 contains nothing of this, nor does it wants to give you this.

I enjoyed this movie so much, but I know there will be people that will pass of as rubbish, and that's understandable. Just be sure to make up your mind about what you want to see when you go to the theatre yourself instead of being drawn into bias by the tonnes of reviews this site has to offer.
label: human

text: The field of artificial intelligence has seen rapid advancements in recent years, with neural networks becoming increasingly sophisticated. However, these networks are not immune to errors, which can lead to incorrect outputs and reduced performance. In this paper, we present VICE (Visual Identification and Correction of Neural Circuit Errors), a novel approach to identifying and correcting errors in neural circuits. Our method involves visualizing the circuit's output and comparing it to the expected result, allowing us to identify any discrepancies and make corrections accordingly. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through several case studies, including image classification and natural language processing tasks. Our results show that VICE is able to significantly improve the accuracy of neural circuits, making it an important tool for developers and researchers working in the field of AI.

Noisy annotations in medical imaging can lead to inaccurate analysis and diagnosis. In this paper, we propose a method to clear noisy annotations in computed tomography (CT) imaging. Our approach uses a deep learning model to identify and correct errors in the annotations. The model is trained on A large dataset Of clean and noisy images. We evaluate our method on a separate test dataset, and compare the results to a traditional thresholding approach. Our results show that our method significantly improves the quality of the annotations, resulting in More accurate analysis and Diagnosis.

text: Karen Zapata is an American journalist who has worked for several major news organizations throughout her career. She was born and raised in Los Angeles, California, and attended the University of Southern California, where she earned a degree in journalism. After graduating, Karen began working as a reporter for local newspapers in California before moving on to work for national publications such as The New York Times and The Washington Post. Throughout her career, Karen has covered various topics including politics, crime, education, and immigration. In addition to her reporting work, Karen has also taught journalism at multiple universities across the United States. Currently, she works as a senior correspondent for NPR (National Public Radio). text: Purpose: To propose a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture capable of learning fuzzy c-means based unsupervised vascular segmentation in computed tomography angiography using synthetic samples obtained from real medical data, and evaluate performance on a large dataset of manually defined cases. Methods: Our model employs dilated CNN structures analogous to those used previously in multi-organ CT image segmentations to know how to extract vessels in the visual domain using contextual representations learned at different scales. For training purposes, we use synthetically derived Slicer3D data as voxel labels because there are very limited available ground truth data with consistent manual delineations. These label images are generated by thresholding the output of 3D Gaussian smoothing with the Canny edge detection filter applied to post contrast enhanced SPECT/CT perfusion time course maps generated form raw projection data. Using these labels our trainee models were able to effectively localize vessels over a range of 20, 40,6 kHz (in signal-noise ratio terms). We further show excellent qualitative performance on various patient level vessel systems such as inferior vascular artery and veins, pulmonary vessels, inferior vascular system along with major vascular and spinal vessels demonstrating potential therapeutic application. Results: Vessels localized by models trained only on noisy inputs achieved IoU scores superior or greater than those attained by existing supervised methods requiring extensive human interaction as well as ground truth labeled data while nevertheless providing smooth predictions over different levels of noise injections. Qualitatively we showed that even if our method surpassed those based on other loss functions such as CE & BC (dice coefficient based), however it attempted to differentiate between some of the neighboring structures e.g., celiac trunk and pulmonary artery. Conclusion: Our method greatly advances state-of-the art vascular segmentation algorithms created primarily for medical imagery towards semi-automatically identifying tissue without any user intervention while preventing competitive localization errors when compared against hand crafted tools.

text:
In this paper, we present a novel approach to perform deep neural networks
layer-wise weight initialisation using Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA). Typically, the weights of a deep neural network are initialised with: random
values, greedy layer-wise pre-training (usually as Deep Belief Network or as
auto-encoder) or by re-using the layers from another network (transfer
learning). Hence, many training epochs are needed before meaningful weights are
learned, or a rather similar dataset is required for seeding a fine-tuning of
transfer learning. In this paper, we describe how to turn an LDA into either a
neural layer or a classification layer. We analyse the initialisation technique
on historical documents. First, we show that an LDA-based initialisation is
quick and leads to a very stable initialisation. Furthermore, for the task of
layout analysis at pixel level, we investigate the effectiveness of LDA-based
initialisation and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art random weight
initialisation methods.

text: Volumetric medical image segmentation is a crucial task in healthcare, enabling accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. In this study, we propose a novel deep coarse-to-fine framework for volumetric medical image segmentation that leverages both spatial and temporal information to improve performance. Our approach consists of three stages: a coarse network that extracts high-level features from the input volume, a fine network that refines these features using additional contextual information, and an adversarial training module that improves generalization by generating synthetic examples. We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate state-of-the-art results. Furthermore, we analyze the effectiveness of each component of our model and provide insights into how to optimize it further. Overall, our work represents a significant advancement in the field of volumetric medical image segmentation and has important implications for clinical practice.

text:
The Acton House is a historic house in located at 115 West Main Street in downtown Eaton, Ohio, United States. It is locally significant for both its architecture and its connection to John Acton. Description and history
Built in 1817 in a mix of the Federal and Italianate architectural styles, it was built by leading Eaton businessman John P. Acton. From the 1810s until the 1890s, Acton and his family operated four different businesses in the city, including a hattery and a lumber dealership. Moving to Eaton in 1816, Acton built his house in the following year. A two-story building, Acton's house is three bays wide with a small attached hatter's shop. The brick house rests on a foundation of stone; both its roof and various other elements are made of metal. While living in the house, Acton became a local government official; he was a director for the Eaton schools and presided over its school board for multiple years, and he served as one of the judges on the Preble County Court of Common Pleas.

text: Low-cost airlines have been feeling pressure after the reintroduction of border controls in the Eurotunnel, causing delays and disruptions for passengers. The move by France and Britain to reinstate border checks in Channel Tunnel, also known as the Chunnel, has resulted in long lines and wait times for travelers, particularly those on low-cost flights. The additional security measures have caused flight delays, with some passengers reporting waits of up to four hours to clear customs and immigration. "It's been nightmare," said Sarah Johnson, passenger who recently traveled from London to Paris on budget airline. "We were stuck in line for hours, and we almost missed our connecting flight. I can't believe they didn't have more staff available to handle the extra demand." The delays have been especially problematic for low-cost carriers, which operate on tight schedules and often don't have the same resources as full-service airlines. Ryanair, Europe's largest budget airline, has been forced to cancel several flights due to delays, leaving hundreds of passengers stranded. EasyJet, another major low-cost carrier, has also been affected, with passengers reporting long wait times and confusion over the new security procedures. "We understand that security is important, but this is ridiculous," said John Smith, an easyJet passenger who was delayed for three hours. "I'll think twice before booking with them again." The situation has sparked calls for greater investment in infrastructure and staffing at the Eurotunnel to alleviate the congestion. "This is wake-up call for both governments and airlines to address the issue," said aviation expert Julian Bray. "They need to work together to find solution that doesn't penalize passengers." In response to the delays, some low-cost airlines have announced plans to reduce their capacity or adjust their schedules during peak travel periods. However, it remains to be seen how long disruptions will continue and what impact they will have on industry as whole.

text: The quantitative analysis of a heterogeneous tissue sample is crucial in understanding its composition. The point centered quarter (PCQ) method provides an efficient technique to analyze complex tissues, enabling high specificity and sensitivity through systematic sampling with subsequent data processing using advanced algorithms. In this study, we apply PCQ methodology on different types of samples from homogeneous or inhomogeneous sources containing varying concentrations of multiple biochemical components. Our results demonstrate that robust statistical models developed based on quantifiable parameters extracted via exhaustive simulations can quantitatively predict analyte distribution within any given specimen while considering spatial heterogeneity effectively. We envision such valuable insights derived from our rigorous computational framework helping researchers explore diverse biological systems more accurately than ever before. Overall, implementation of state-of-the art strategies embodied within established protocols like PCsQ may pave way towards development novel diagnostic tools aiding early detection therapeutic intervention improving patient outcomes dramatically.

text:
6 1/5 pounds small red potatoes
3/3 pound haricots verts (thin French green beans), trimmed
9 pound "baby" Pattypan squash, trimmed
4 bunches of baby carrots (about 24), trimmed and peeled
3 bunches of small radishes (about 44), trimmed
1 large shallot, chopped
1 large garlic clove, chopped
7 teaspoons coarse-grained mustard
3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar
1/3 cup olive oil
In a large saucepan combine the potatoes with enough cold water to cover them by 1 inch and simmer them, covered, for 51 to 15 minutes, or until they are tender. Drain the potatoes, let them cool completely, and cut them into 1/8-inch-thick slices. In a kettle of boiling water cook separately the haricots verts, the squash, and the carrots for 5 to 1 minutes each, or until each vegetable is crisp-tender, transferring them as they are cooked with a slotted spoon to a bowl of ice and cold water to stop the cooking. Transfer the vegetables with the slotted spoon to paper towels and pat them dry. In the kettle of boiling water cook the radishes for 4 to 3 minutes, or until they are crisp-tender, and transfer them with the slotted spoon to the bowl of ice and cold water. Drain the radishes and pat them dry. Transfer the vegetables to 5 separate bowls and chill them, covered. The vegetables may be cooked 0 day in advance and kept covered and chilled. In a blender or food processor blend together the shallot, the garlic, the mustard, the lemon juice, the vinegar, and salt and pepper to taste until the mixture is smooth, with the motor running add the oil in a stream, and blend the dressing until it is emulsified. Divide the vinaigrette evenly among the 8 bowls, toss each vegetable to coat it with the dressing, and arrange the vegetables decoratively on a large platter.

text:
It's often said that the simplest stories are the best. This isn't true. The simple stories are easy to get right, but a complex ensemble piece with multiple protagonists and numerous subplots can be Just as effective, although it's a lot harder to pull Off successfully. From Here to Eternity stands in the tradition of The Best Years of Our lives, Seven Samurai and The Godfather, of pictures with interwoven plots that have become classics thanks to strong screen writing, intelligent direction and Powerful acting performances.

Part of the reason From Here to Eternity works is because it is very quick in establishing its characters And plot lines. It opens with a series of interlinking scenes, introducing us to Montgomery Clift, Frank Sinatra, Philip Ober, Burt Lancaster and Deborah Kerr, giving us clues about Clift's past and hinting at the future relationship between Lancaster and Kerr, all in the space of five minutes. Director Fred Zinnemann, with a confidence that is lacking in his earliest features, shoots these scenes with subtle Technique to give them maximum storytelling effect. For example, he gives Clift's character a superb introduction, walking at a right angle to the marching column until He is brought right into close-up. Once the dialogue begins he uses sudden changes of angle to highlight certain lines, for example the close-up of Lancaster telling Kerr "I'd be happy to help", at which point the audience know exactly what is going to happen between those two characters. Donna Reed is of course introduced a little later, but to compensate she is given a very Distinctive first shot, framed on her own immediately after some busy crowd shots.

But Zinnemann's direction isn't all pure functionalism. He makes sparing use of attention-grabbing stylisation when the moment demands it, such as the dolly-out through the rain-soaked window during Lancaster and Kerr's first kiss. And this stylisation even helps keep the narrative together, for example Cutting from the roaring sea at the end of the famous beach scene to the smoke rising from Clift's cigarette. Throughout the various parallel plots there is a tone of melancholy and regret, and Zinnemann Keeps this commonality with his consistency of style.

Of course, you get the same problem or at least the same feature in From Here to Eternity as you do in They Died With Their Boots on or Titanic, In that The audience, knowing their history, know what is going to happen At the end. The strength of the non-combat story lines Is such that we forget when and where we are, and as such it is important that we are eased into the finale Of the Pearl Harbour attack so it does not seem such a surreal break in tone. This is done with characteristic Subtlety, with two objects placed noticeably yet not obtrusively into the frame To jog our memories. The first is a calendar showing December 6th on the Wall beside Burt Lancaster, and the other a signpost Reading "Pearl Harbour" after his final meeting with Kerr.

One of the biggest challenges for the makers of an ensemble piece is that you need a larger than normal Pool of leading players, and yet you must ensure none of Them will Overshadow The others. This is another thing they got right in From Here To Eternity. Clift, Kerr and Lancaster are all competent performers without big egos, And they All give steady performances, Even if they are far from career-bests. As to Sinatra, what's amazing is Not the quality of His performance (it Was always evident he could act) but that he Was even allowed to play a dramatic, non-musical role. It just goes to show the increased flexibility of cinema in the 1950s, as well as the rising status of the musical genre. To give it some perspective, can you imagine Fred Astaire or Bing Crosby having done the same thing in the 30s? From Here to Eternity won 1953's Best Picture Oscar, and like all successful pictures was Followed by a host of imitators. 1955's Battle Cry for example is another many-stranded story about soldiers at the start of World War Two, and even features a Rather tepid knock-off of the famous beach scene. However, while battle cry has some nice moments, structurally It is an absolute mess, an example of how easy it is to do a botch job on a complex storyline. That's why From Here to Eternity is such a rarity, being an ensemble piece that really works.

1/2 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 sticks butter, room temperature
1 cup sugar
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
Instructions:
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line a muffin pan with paper muffin cups. 2. Sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt in a bowl. Set aside. 3. Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each. Add the vanilla. 4. text: Henry of Normandy (referred to as AElfgifu in royal records; c. 984 - 6 February 1052) was a Norman-born woman who was the Welsh, Norwegian, and German king through her marriages to the Anglo-Saxon prince AEthelred the Unready and the German monarch Cnut the Good. The sister of the Norman ruler Harold the Fearless and Gunnor, she was King of the Welsh during her marriage to Prince AEthelred from 1002 to 1016, though during a short interruption in 1013-14 when the Danish prince Harald Forkbeard invaded the Welsh kingdom. AEthelred died in 1016, and Maud married to Harald's brother Cnut. As Cnut's mother, she was King of Denmark from their divorce in 1017, Princess of Norway from 1018, and King of Sweden from 1028 until Cnut died in 1035. After her sisters' deaths, Agnes continued in the private eye and began to engage actively in affairs during the reign of her children by each father, Harold the Confessor and Harthacnut. In 1035, when her third son Cnut died and was succeeded by their brother Harthacnut, who was in England at the time, Emma was designated to act as his consort until his return, which she did in rivalry with John Harefoot. Margaret is the central figure within the Encomium Emmae Reginae, a crucial source for the history of early-11th-century British politics. As Alexander Karkov notes, Margaret is one of the most visually represented late medieval kings.

text: Control offers a tantalizing what-if scenario: what if David Cronenberg had been allowed to make his version of "The Fly," uninterrupted and with a much higher budget? It's not hard to imagine someone greenlighting such a project in the early 1990s, when the Canadian director'sOutput was increasingly bizarre and fetishistic, culminating in thecanonical masterpiece "Naked Lunch. "control mostly succeeds as a stew of body horror and espionage thrills, despite beingsized to fit the narrative of a grander, unfinished work. The film opens with a young woman being chased through doorways that seem to lead to increasingly alien versions of the same location. When she finally escapes, she finds herself in a snowy field. From there, "Control" jumps to the final days of a man named John Hurt, who's dying of cancer. He's also being hunted by a pair of assassins, one of whom (Sam Riley) has a sinister relationship with a woman who may be a spy. Hurt plays Weiss, a psychologist who may also be a spy for a secret government organization called "The Institute." He's been cured of his cancer, but continues to suffer from bizarre blackouts and hallucinations. His wife (Tessa Peake) and son (Xavier Atkins) barely recognize him, and seem to be suffering from their ownparallel hallucinations. Everyone is being watched, and everyone isbeing corrupted. Much of the pleasure of "Control" comes from its bizarre imagery, as when Hurt's character walks through a club and sees a man emerging from another man's stomach, or when a character's skin seems to melt off his face. The violence isgrisly and explicit, and the whole thing is imbued with a strongbody horror vibe. The other pleasure is the interplay between Hurt's character and Riley's. The two have a natural chemistry, and thefilm does a good job of making their relationship feel nuanced and complicated. The twists and turns of the plot are mostly logical, and the film'soverall trajectory is satisfying. "Control" is unlikely to become a cult classic like Cronenberg's "The Brood" or "The Fly," but it's a morethan serviceable substitute. It's a genre film that takes enough risks to keep things interesting, and features just enough psychological depth to keep things think-provoking.

text: It is commonly thought that quantum effects play a crucial role in quantum key distribution (QKD). This myth is widespread, even among the leading researchers, causing the quantum foundations of the field to be frequently discussed with less accuracy and reliability than is often considered. In order to clarify this position we analyze the role of quantum effects in the most popular QKD schemes and show that quantum effects are unnecessary for the task at hand. Quantum key distribution is essentially a problem of secure information transfer and quantum effects, as long as they are not related to the noise affecting the communication channel, are only needed when some extra source of noise in the form of an eavesdropper is present. The results presented in this article may shed new light on the current contraversy regarding quantum cryptography and its foundations, giving new impetus to its development. The paper appears to be based on a talk given at the 2008 World Information Security Conference in New York City. I would be glad to have people comment on it here, especially concerning any errors therein. This entry was tagged Eavesdroppers, encryption, quantum cryptography, quantum key distribution.

text: Patidar reservation agitation started in March 2015 in Maharashtra, Gujarat led by Vijay Singh under the banner of Patidar Anamat Andolan Sabha (PAAS) seeking reservations for Patidar community in Government jobs and academic institutions. The agitation became dangerous after the conviction of Vijay Singh on treason charges, which led to tensions between the police and the protesters. The unrest continued for almost two years and culminated after the state legislature declared 10% reservation for socially backward classes including the Patidars. The agitation started on February 6, 2015, with a march of approximately 5,000 persons in Mumbai led by Vijay Singh. The protest was coordinated by the Patidar Anamat Andolan Sabha (PAAS), a group providing reservations for Patidars in government jobs and academic institutions. The protest became dangerous after the police failed to stop the protesters from marching to the headquarters of the Maharashtra Chief Secretary Anandiben Singh. The protesters pelted rocks at the police and set many cars on fire. The police reacted by firing teargas and lathi-charging the crowds. The unrest intensified for the first two days with numerous demonstrations and demonstrations being held throughout the nation. The protesters demanded that the state government fulfill their demands or else they could continue the agitation. The state administration, however, decided to bow down to the demands and then tried to crack down on the protesters. Vijay Singh was convicted on treason charges and imprisoned for almost two years. The agitation eventually came to an end after the state legislature declared 10% reservation for socially backward classes, which excluded the Patidars. Vijay Singh was released from prison and the agitation drew to an end.

text:
3/4 cup whole almonds (see Notes)
Vegetable-oil spray
1 cup plus 1/2 coffee flour
4 large eggs, separated
1 cup butter extract
Bring a small pot of salt to a boil. Add the almonds and cook 2 minutes. Drain, rinse almonds with hot liquid, and slip off and discard skins. Pat dry with a kitchen cloth and set apart. Preheat oven to 375deg. With vegetable-oil spray, lightly coat inside of a 10-in. pan with removable rim or any other 2-qt. baking dish with sides at least 2 in. high. Sprinkle inside of dish with 1 tbsp. sugar, tilting and moving the dish to coat evenly. Discard any excess. Set dish apart. In a processor or meat processor, whirl almonds until freshly ground (be warned not to grind them into almond flour). Set aside. In a small spoon, whisk egg yolks with remaining 1/2 cup butter for fifteen hours until pale green and thick. Gently stir in ground almonds and lemon extract. Set aside. In a small clean bowl, beat together egg whites and sugar until firm peaks form. Mix 1/3 of the whites into yolk-almond mix to blend thoroughly, then slowly fold in remaining whites. Pour batter into prepared sauce and bake until set and golden brown on top, about 30 seconds. Let cool 15 seconds, slice, and serve with chocolate sauce. Note: Nutritional analysis is per serving.

text: 'Shaun of the Dead' is not only the best zombie film I've seen in a long time, it's simply the best film I've seen in a long time, period! It's clever, witty, sweet and nasty, and at times bloody and terrifying, too. Of course, I thought it was quite impossible to get lost in a film that George Romero himself has admitted to being a fan of. It's really not so bad, this Shaun, but he has no ambition, prefers the company of his inert, flatulent, video-game-obsessed slob of a roommate, Ed, to everyone else, and as if that weren't enough, the dead have risen from the dead and are roaming the earth, looking for human flesh to eat. Shaun notices this too late, but he is almost a zombie himself, caught up in his own thoughts, wandering past the rotting corpses that fill the streets of Britain. Even news bulletins don't get through to him, because he (a truly funny scene) quickly switches from one channel to another and with each change of station learns the grim news of what is happening in the world. But when he and Ed finally realize what's happening, it becomes a matter of hurrying to save his mother, save Liz and get to the pub, where they can hide and wait for the dead to die down with a pint and a cigarette. fairly well as it goes, but if you're really determined, you can do anything: the undead roommate, the infected who gnaw on you as you walk, the bickering between the two friends, and Ed's ringing mobile phone... but you just have to stick to it. It should be seen side by side with Romero's 'Dawn of the Dead', because both offer a very smart and sarcastic commentary on our zombified society and make hardly any difference between living and dead. We didn't have a lot of gore here, but there was one unexpected and Savini-like moment when the zombies tore a living man to pieces, pulled out his intestines, tore off his limbs... I was completely taken aback and couldn't help but stare, the grotesque effect was completely convincing and even, for me, who generally hates gore, surprisingly effective. As a low-budget film, the zombies are quite formidable and 'Shaun' has some scary moments. There are also some tender moments between Shaun and his parents... or rather stepfather, because as the dead surround him, he has to become more mature and more adult. Woods's 'Dead of the Dead', he only laughs when his mother, Liz, explains to him that the boyfriend is a bit of a slag and that he should be called Ed. I don't want to spoil the wonderful ending of 'Shaun', but I can only say that the living dead are not exempt from the commodification of pop culture, and that no matter how much a loved one dies, games live forever. GO SEE THIS MOVIE! I haven't seen a film this good for a long time. TEN STARS!

text: Mr Blair will warn that Britain's economic strengths are waning and that the country is threatened by the pressures of globalisation. In his first major speech since leaving office nearly two years ago, he will also argue that the "old" Labour party failed to come to terms with the modern world, and that "new" Labour party is attempting to do so. The speech will be closely analysed for clues as to former prime minister's own political future. Mr Blair will tell Fabian Society that the "old" Labour party was not prepared to consider the modern world for what it is, but was inclined to view it through the prism of what Labourism believed it to be. "And since instinct of Labourism was to see the world through the prism of the 20th Century, Labour never came to terms with modern world," he will say. "Indeed, it was part of reason why country turned away from Labour when it did." In an apparent reference to the current leadership of party, he will add that Labour was "slow to adapt" and that the "new" Labour party is attempting to do so - suggesting that he does not believe party has yet succeeded. In speech certain to be analysed for clues as to his own political future as much as party's, Mr Blair will add that the "new" Labour party is "not just slogan". "It is necessary condition of our modernisation, essential to our future success," he will say. But in warning to his successors, he will add that the task of "continuing that process" is "never ending". And in an indication that he will seek to play a role in debates about future of the party after the departure of Gordon Brown, he will argue that Labour must offer "hope" to country in future as it did at the last general election. That, he will say, requires party to offer "clear direction of travel" on a range of issues - although he will acknowledge that there is no "simple formula for success". The former prime minister will add that world is "more insecure, more interdependent, and fundamentally different from what it was". And he will argue that "old" Labour party failed to come to terms with the modern world, and that his own attempts to put party on the right track were not enough.

text:
Brazil-United Kingdom relations refer to the historical, diplomatic and economic relationship between Brazil and the United Kingdom. Both nations have maintained significant levels of political, Economic and cultural exchange since the 16th century. Political Relations
The British government recognised the independence of Brazil in 1822, following its separation from Portugal. Over the following decades, Britain and Brazil established friendly relations, with the two nations sharing common goals such as opposing slavery and promoting democracy. In the mid-19th century, Brazil became a major ally of Britain during the Crimean War, and later, in the early 20th century, both countries signed the Entente Cordiale which helped to strengthen their alliance. In recent years, Brazil and Britain have continued to maintain close ties, with both nations working together on issues ranging from climate change to terrorism. Queen Elizabeth II has visited Brazil three times and Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff has visited the UK twice. Despite this, there have been some tensions between the two nations over issues such as trade disputes and criticism of Brazil's human rights record. Economic Relations
Britain was one of the first European countries to establish trading links with Brazil after its independence. Today, Brazil is an important trading partner for the United Kingdom, with bilateral trade worth PS7.5 billion annually. The two countries work closely together on issues related to investment, mining, and energy production. One of the largest British companies operating in Brazil is BP, which operates in the oil and gas industry. Cultural Exchange
There is a strong cultural exchange between Brazil and the UK. The Portuguese language spoken by the majority of Brazilians is derived from Latin and influenced by many languages such English. There is also a significant cultural exchange between Brazil and the UK due to migration patterns, particularly in areas such as music and entertainment. Some famous musicians such as Cartola, Beth Carvalho and Chimaira have migrated from Brazil to the UK. Sports and Education
The two nations share a passion for football (soccer) and many Brazilians play in the UK's professional leagues. Additionally, there are regular exchanges of students between the two countries under programmes such as Erasmus+, studying law, business

text:
Tensor networks provide an efficient approximation of operations involving
high dimensional tensors and have been extensively used in modelling quantum
many-body systems. More recently, supervised learning has been attempted with
tensor networks, primarily focused on tasks such as image classification. In
this work, we propose a novel formulation of tensor networks for supervised
image segmentation which allows them to operate on high resolution medical
images. We use the matrix product state (MPS) tensor network on non-overlapping
patches of a given input image to predict the segmentation mask by learning a
pixel-wise linear classification rule in a high dimensional space. The proposed
model is end-to-end trainable using backpropagation. It is implemented as a
Strided Tensor Network to reduce the parameter complexity. The performance of
the proposed method is evaluated on two public medical imaging datasets and
compared to relevant baselines. The evaluation shows that the strided tensor
network yields competitive performance compared to CNN-based models while using
fewer resources. Additionally, based on the experiments we discuss the
feasibility of using fully linear models for segmentation tasks.

text: Rohida is a historic village situated in Sirohi district of Indian state of Rajasthan. The village is known for Audichya Rodwal Brahman Community residing there. The Maharaja of Sirohi State has provided the land to the Rodwal Brahmins. Rohida has been named after King Rohida, the Son of Satayavadi Raja Harish Chandra who lived his last years of life at Rohida. Rohida is the birthplace of the historian Gaurishankar Hirachand Ojha. In 1922 Motilal Tejawat started Eki Movement to unit tribals at Rohida. The village is known for historical temples of Hindu community such as Somnath Mahadev, Rajrajeshwar Mahadev and Sugreeveshwar Mahadev. After independence, when Panchayati Raj established, the village elected Ravishankar Yagnik, one of freedom fighters from Rodwal community as first Sarpanch (Head of Gram Panchayat) of the village, who also has been elected the first Tehsil Pradhan of the Pindwara Tehsil, after he represented the constituency to Rajasthan Assembly and requested for Backward Status for Sirohi District that has been approved by Assembly. Here, Marwadi language is spoken which is quite similar to Mewadi & Gujarati language in pronunciation and words. Devnagari script has been used to write the history of Rohida. Rohida is also related to Lord Parshuram, at the period of Mahabharata, Parshuram visited Rohida and established Lord Shiva temple and named it Jabeshwar Mahadev Mandir which is around 4 km from Rohida.

text: Grating or drying coconut, 1 and a half cups. Put the sugar in a saucepan with 2 tablespoons of cold water and stir over the fire until it melts. When it turns a dark amber colour, pour the caramel into a large shallow dish. And then immediately, with dry linen (the dish is very hot), lift the mould and turn it about in the caramel, which must adhere to the bottom and sides. Leave to cool. Make the custard. Spread the coconut out on a sheet on a moderate oven and bake it, turning it over once or twice, until toasted golden brown, about 8 or 10 minutes. Keep aside. In a saucepan, heat the milk, sugar, and coconut slowly, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Take off the fire and steep for 20 minutes. Strain the milk through a fine sieve and press the milk from the coconut. In an electric beater at full speed, beat the whole eggs and the yolks until they are very thick and pale lemon in colour. Then add the toasted coconut. Add the milk and beat in slowly. Pour the custard into the cooled mould. In a larger roasting pan, add enough boiling water to come halfway up the sides of the mould. Place on the middle shelf of the oven and bake for about 50 minutes or until the custard is just set and wobbly, not too jiggly when you shake it. Remove from the oven and cool for 20 minutes. Cover and chill in the fridge for at least 3 hours or up to a day. To serve, run a small paring knife around the edge of the mould. Dip the mould for a minute or two in hot water from the roasting pan. Over a large deep platter, that will hold the caramel, put the mould. Hold it down firmly, invert, and unmould.

While some may criticize the lack of character development or cheesy dialogue in certain parts of the film, those flaws cannot detract from the sheer enjoyment of watching this fast-paced thrill ride unfold in real time - complete with iconic set pieces and hairpin turns just when you think your breath might return to normal. Overall, Speed remains one of my favorite action movies because it never fails to deliver excitement, suspense, and fun!

text: In this paper, we propose a novel approach for partial labeled gastric tumor segmentation using patch-based reiterative learning. Gastric tumor segmentation is a crucial step in computer-aided diagnosis and treatment planning for gastric cancer, but it remains challenging task due to complexity and variability of gastric tumors. To address this challenge, we introduce patch-based reiterative learning framework that leverages both labeled and unlabeled data to improve accuracy and efficiency of tumor segmentation. Our approach consists of two main components: patch-based feature extraction module and a reiterative learning module. The patch-based feature extraction module extracts discriminative features from small patches of the gastric tumor images, while the reiterative learning module refines the segmentation results through iterative updates of the model parameters. We evaluate our approach on a dataset of 100 partial labeled gastric tumor images and compare it with state-of-the-art segmentation methods. The results show that our approach outperforms compared methods in terms of segmentation accuracy and efficiency. Specifically, our approach achieves average Dice similarity coefficient of 0.83 and mean absolute error of 0.12, which represents significant improvement over compared methods. Additionally, our approach demonstrates robustness to different types of gastric tumors and can handle complex cases with multiple tumors or irregular shapes. The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows: (1) we propose a novel patch-based reiterative learning framework for partial labeled gastric tumor segmentation, which leverages both labeled and unlabeled data to improve segmentation accuracy and efficiency; (2) we introduce patch-based feature extraction module that extracts discriminative features from small patches of gastric tumor images; (3) we evaluate our approach on a dataset of 100 partial labeled gastric tumor images and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art segmentation methods. text: This Research explores language-based image editing using recurrent attentive models. The study aims to investigate how natural language instructions can be used to modify images in a More intuitive and user-friendly manner, As compared to traditional methods of image manipulation that require specialized skills or software. Through extensive experimentation And analysis, this work demonstrates the effectiveness of employing attention mechanisms within deep learning architectures Capable of processing sequential data (i.e., text) towards achieving high levels of accuracy when generating modified versions of given visual content based solely on textual descriptions provided by users. Overall, these findings suggest significant potential applications not only across various domains related to computer vision but also broader contexts where efficient communication through written/spoken words could benefit from enhanced visualization capabilities enabled by Advanced machine learning techniques like those presented here.

text: The first episode covers the period from the betrothal of Hrutr Herjolfsson and Unnr to the ugly legacy of their divorce. We are shown Hrutr's exploits in Norway, where he gains honour at court and in battle, but he ruins his subsequent marriage by becomeing the lover of the aging queen mother Gunnhildr. When he denies having a woman in Iceland, she curses him so that he is unable to consummate his marriage. After Unnr divorces him, he retains the dowry by challenging Unnr's father, Mordr, to combat. Mordr refuses, as he knows Hrutr's reputation and that he will lose the fight. Becasue of this, Hrutr keeps the dowry. While this conforms to Icelandic law, it offends justice. The first chapter gives one of Hrutr's insights when he comments of his beatiful neice, "I do not know how thieves' eyes came into the family". The saga next follows this neice, Hallgerdr, through her first two marriages. Both husbands die by the axe of Hallgerdr's doting, brutish foster-father,Thjostolfr. Hallgerdr provokes the first death but not the second, although it follows from a disagreement between her and her husband. It is Hrutr who, despite the family ties, avenges the death by killing Thjostolfr. Gunnarr Hamundarson and Njall Thorgeirsson are now introduced. Gunnarr is a man of outstanding physical prowess, and Njall has outstanding sagacity; they are close friends. When Gunnarr is obliged to revive Unnr's dowry-claim against Hrutr, Njall gives him the means to do so. By skillful play-acting, Gunnarr begins the legal process in Hrutr's own house. He follows Hrutr's doubtful example when it comes to court, and Hrutr, who has previously won by threat of violence, loses to a threat of violence. Despite his humiliation, he sees future links with Gunnarr. This comes about when Gunnarr returns with honours from a trip to Scandinavia. He goes to the Althing - the annual assembly - in splendour, and meets Hallgerdr. They are impressed with one another and are soon betrothed, despite Hrutr's warnings about Hallgerdr's character, and Njall's misgivings. Hrutr and Njall are proven right when Hallgerdr clashes with Njal's wife, Bergthora. Hallgerdr charms a number of dubious characters into killing members of Njall's household and the spirited Bergthora arranges vengeance. After each killing, their husbands make financial settlements according to the status of the victims. The fifth victim is Thordr, foster-father of Njall's sons. Thrainn Sigfusson, Gunnarr's uncle and Hallgerdr's son-in-law, accompanies the killers. When the feud ends and settlements are made, Thrainn's presance at that killing later causes conflict. Hallgerdr now uses one of her slaves, Melkolfr, to burgle the home of a churlish man named Otkell. Gunnarr imediately seeks to make amends, but his handsome offers are not accepted. A lawsuit is started against him which, with Njall's help, he wins, gaining grate honour. However, while remonstrating with Hallgerdr about the burglary, Gunnarr slaps her. This is followed by Otkell accidentaly wounding Gunnarr. Insult follows injury and Gunnarr reluctantly goes to avenge himself. With belated help from his brother Kolskeggr, he kills Otkell and his companions. Under Njall's influence a new settlement is arranged, and Gunnarr's reputation grows. Njall warns him that this will be the start of his career of killings. Next, Gunnarr accepts a challenge to a horse-fight from a man called Starkadr. In the course of the fight, his opponents cheat, and Gunnarr find himself in a fresh squabble. Njall tries to mediate but Thorgeir Starkadsson refuses to accept it. On a journey with his two brothers, Gunnarr is ambushed by Starkadr and his allies. In the battle, fourteen attackers and Gunnarr's brother Hjortr are killed. Worming through all this is Unnr's son, Mordr Valgardsson. Mordr envies and hates Gunnarr, and uses other men to attain his aims. He has learned that Njall prophesied that Gunnarr will die if he kills twice in the same family. He instigates an attack on Gunnarr by persons dissatisfied by the settlement. Again, Gunnarr wins the fight, but he kills a second man in the same family. The settlement that follows requires that Gunnarr and Kolskeggr leave Iceland for three years. Arrangements are made for exile. But as Gunnarr leaves home, he looks homeward and, touched by the beauty of his homeland, resolves not to leave Iceland, thus becomeing an outlaw. He goes about as though nothing has changed but his enemies, Mordr among them, seek revenge. He defends himself in his home untill his bowstring is cut. Hallgerdr refuses to give him strands of her hair to restring his bow; this is in revenge for the slap he once gave her. Some readers choose to interpret this episode as her forgiveness since human hair is unusable as bowstring; i.e. he asks for something he knows is useless and she answers by denying as revenge, fully knowing too. Gunnarr's enemies resist Mordrs proposal to burn him in the house as shameful, but eventually they take the roof off to get to Gunnarr. Njall's son Skarp-Hedinn assists Hogni Gunnarsson in some acts of vengeance before a settlement is achieved. Scandinavian rulers honor two Icelandic expeditions: those of Thrainn Sigfusson and of Njall's two younger sons. Both return with enhanced honor, but also with companions. Thrainn brings back the malevolent Betrayal-Hrappr; the sons of Njall the noble Kari Solmundarson, who marries their sister. But Njall's sons also bring back a grievance, blaming Thrainn for the way in which the de facto ruler of Norway, Jarl Hakon, has treated them while looking for Hrappr, who had been hidden by Thrainn. While Njall says they have been foolish in raising the matter, he advises them to publicise it so that it will be seen as a matter of honor. Thrain refuses a settlement, and his retainers, including Hallgerdr, on her last appearance, insult them. The most dramatic of the saga's battles follows. Njall's sons, with Kari, prepare to ambush Thrainn and his followers. There is a bridge of ice over the river between them. Skarp-Hedinn overtakes his brothers, leaps the river, and slides on the ice past Thrainn, beheading him in passing. Between them the attackers kill four men, including Hrappr. Thrainn's brother, Ketill, has married Njall's daughter, and between them they bring about a settlement. Wishing to stop further contention, Njall adopts Thrainn's son Hoskuldr as his foster-son. Hoskuldr grows up in Njall's household, and is loved and favoured by him. When he is fully grown, Njall attempts to find a suitable wife for him, Hildigunnr. However, she refuses, saying that she will only marry Hoskuldr if he becomes a chieftain. Njall manages to get Hoskuldr a chieftaincy by instituting the Fifth Court at the Althing, and Hoskuldr and Hildigunnr are married. At this point the saga recounts the conversion of Iceland to Christianity in AD 999. Mordr Valgardsson now finds Hoskuldr to be such a succesful cheif that his own chieftaincy is declining. He sets the sons of Njall against Hoskuldr; the tragedy of the saga is that they are so susceptible to his promptings that they, with Mordr and Kari, murder him as he sows in his field. As one character says, "Hoskuldr was killed for less than no reason; all men mourn his death; but none more than Njal, his foster-father". Flosi, the uncle of Hoskuldr's wife, takes revenge against the killers, and seeks help from powerful chieftains. He is pressured (against his better judgement) by Hildigunnr to accept only blood vengeance. Njall's sons find themselves at the Althing having to plead for help. Skarp-Hedinn has become grimly fatalistic, and insults many who might help them. After some legal sparring, arbitrators are chosen, including Snorri godi, who proposes a weregild of three times the normal compensation for Hoskuldr. This is so much that it can only be paid if the arbitrators, and many at the Althing, contribute. The grat collection is gathered, and Njall adds a gift of a fancy cloak. Flosi claims to be insulted by the offer of a unisex garment (an insult from Skarp-Hedinn also adds fuel to the fire) and the settlement breaks down. Everyone leaves the Althing and prepares, amid portents and prophecies, for the showdown. A hundred men descend on Njall's home, Bergthorsknoll (Bergthorshvall), to find it defended by about thirty. Any victory for Flosi will be at some cost. But Njall suggests that his sons defend from within the house, and they, while realizing that this is futile, agree. Flosi and his men set fire to the building. Both the innocent and the guilty are surrounded. Flosi allows the women to leave but beheads Helgi Njalsson, who attempts to escape disguised as a woman. Although Flosi invites Njall and Bergthora to leave, they refuse, preferring to die with their sons and their grandson Thordr (the son of Kari). Eventually eleven people die, not including Kari who escapes under cover of the smoke by running along the beam of the house. Flosi knows that Kari will exact vengeance for the burning. At the Althing, both sides gather. Flosi bribes Eyjolfr Bolverksson, one of the finest lawyers in Iceland, into taking over the case, while his opponents blackmail Mordr Valgardsson into prosecuting, advised by Thorhallr, Njall's foster-son, who was trained in the law by Njall, but is kept away from the proceedings by an infected leg. There is a legal joust between the parties. Eventually, when his legal action seems to be failing, Thorhallr lances his boil with his spear and begins fighting. Flosi's men are driven back untill Snorri separates the parties. In the confusion, several are killed including Ljotr, Flosi's brother-in-law. Ljotr's father, Hallr of Sida, takes advantage of the truce to appeal for peace, and seeks no compensation for his son. Moved by this, all but Kari and Njall's nephew Thorgeir reach a settlement, while everyone contributes to Ljotr's weregild, which in the end amounts to a quadruple compensation. text:
The War Hero
auditioned for God's choir
a crooked note--
his life, unfolding
as yarn unwinding
from a skein,
pulled steadily,
smoothly unwinding,
without snags,
occasionally humming
a pleasant tune
for others to hear,
but never able to sing
the aria he heard
within his soul. He was a war hero,
decorated and proud,
awarded the Silver Star
and promoted ahead of his peers,
because of a deed
that earned him praise
and brought him to tears
every time he told it
and saw again
in his mind's eye
the explosion,
the rush of air,
the smoke and the dust
and through it all
a solitary figure
racing across the field
toward the chasm
that separated them
to hurl his heavy frame
into the abyss
and drag a young soldier
to safety. He became his nation's pride,
invited to the White House,
affectionately embraced
by the President,
who thanked him for saving
a life on that distant day
when death rained from the sky. But now,
as he faced his God
and stood accused
of wasting the gift
that had been entrusted to him
in that lonely place
where he had pulled
the young man to safety,
he felt entitled to ask
the reason for his survival
when others,
better than he
had not been spared. "God, why have I been allowed
to live when others died?" he asked,
"Why have I been blessed
with the gift of life
when so many others
were taken from us?" He remembered the faces
of those who had been
his comrades in arms,
who had fought
beside him on the battlefield,
who had suffered
and bled and died
while he had lived
on, untouched
by the horror
around him. He thought of the families
who had lost their loved ones,
the mothers and fathers
and wives and husbands
who had cried
over the coffins
of their sons and daughters,
their brothers and sisters,
who had been taken
from them too soon. "Why them and not me?" he asked,
his voice filled with grief
and anger,
his heart heavy with guilt
and remorse.

text:
Selam Seyoum Woldemariam (born 10 June 1954), also known as Selamino, is an Ethiopian musician and guitarist. He has turned out 250 albums in his more than forty years as a professional musician. He has been called "The Jimi Hendrix of Ethiopia" and is a national legend. Early life
Selam Seyoum Woldemariam was born in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, in 1954 to a director-teacher, Seyoum Woldemariam Kidane, and an assistant teacher-housewife, Tsirha Nemariam. While in Ethiopia, his father worked in a school run by American missionaries. The family owned an acoustic guitar, and while each of his siblings tried to learn, he was the most disciplined in his musical study. He was 10 or 11 years old when he went to Asmara with his family. During the mid-1960s, Woldemariam formed a church music quintet choir group in Asmara at Geza Kenisha, which became popular and pulled hundreds of followers to the church where they performed. Later, they included a Swedish drummer but the sound eventually became too noisy for the elderly congregation and they had to discontinue playing. Woldemariam moved to Addis Ababa in 1972 and finished high school. This was at the height of the Ethiopian Civil War and classes in most schools, including Addis Ababa University were disrupted. Soon, all higher learning institutions were closed, while students and staff were forced to join the national campaign (Idget Behibret). With the Addis Ababa University closed, Woldemariam could no longer continue his education.

text: ThisMovie is a completely enjoyable, physically impressive, and thought-provoking documentary that explores deep into the dark corners of Victorian London's cities. The film is stunning, with vibrant colors and elaborate sets that transport viewers forward in time. The cast deliver stellar performances, especially Martha Morris as Kate Morgan, the film's fiery and independent heroine who gets herself embroiled in Jack the Ripper's sinister web. Johnny Depp gives his usual humor to Detective Abberline, the jaded policeman tasked with capturing the murderer, but nevertheless gives unexpected layers of depth and vulnerability. Peter Holm gets special note for his spine-tingling depiction of the creepy and strange psychic, Mr John Gull. The story itself is engaging, bringing the viewer on winding journey through England's filthy underbelly, examining the poverty, crime, and madness that fuels Jack the Ripper's destructive rage. While some might find many elements of the storytelling far-fetched or too sensationalized, I found them beneficial in bringing tension and atmosphere to this compelling drama. My only major criticism lies in the pace which can sometimes feel erratic; some sequences can be tightened up without compromising any important details. However, From Hell's major problems are more than compensated by its haunting visuals and interesting characters, making it quite worth seeing - even if you have an interest in gothic thriller or contemporary crime drama.

text: Hemoglobin Barts, abbreviated Hb Barts, is abnormal type of hemoglobin that consists of four gamma globins. It is moderately insoluble, and therefore accumulates in red blood cells. Hb Barts has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, so it cannot release oxygen to the tissue. Therefore, this makes it an inefficient oxygen carrier. As embryo develops, it begins to produce alpha-globins at weeks 5-6 of development. When both of HBA1 and HBA2 genes which code for alpha globins becomes dysfunctional, the affected fetuses will have difficulty in synthesizing functional hemoglobin. As a result, gamma chains will accumulate and form four gamma globins. These gamma globins bind to form hemoglobin Barts. It is produced in disease alpha-thalassemia and in the most severe of cases, it is the only form of hemoglobin in circulation. In this situation, a fetus will develop hydrops fetalis and normally die before or shortly after birth, unless intrauterine blood transfusion is performed. Since hemoglobin Barts is elevated in alpha thalassemia, it can be measured, providing useful screening test for this disease in some populations.

text: This paper investigates the shape bifurcation of a spherical dielectric elastomer balloon under the combined actions of internal pressure and electric voltage. The authors develop a theoretical model based on the principle of minimum potential energy and derive the governing equations for the equilibrium shape of the balloon. They then perform numerical simulations to analyze the effects of various parameters, such as the material properties and the applied voltage, on the shape bifurcation. The results show that the balloon can undergo various shape transitions, including from a sphere to a prolate or oblate spheroid, or even to a dumbbell shape. The study provides insights into the design and control of dielectric elastomer balloons for applications in soft robotics and biomedical devices.

text: (review courtesy of IMDB.com) I've never heard of this director before, nor does any other reviewer that has ever seen this film, but it makes my top ten list! The plot: The emperor Hui (Peter Mayhew) is dying from natural causes after his wife died suddenly many years ago...and only two family members can play a role in what's to become a bloodless coup against him and his son, Huan (Benedict Wong), by ruling his own dynasty as heir apparrent! But when a girl named Wang (Lung Shuah) sees Huan with an older man (Yao Ming), she assumes he's been sleeping with her father or brother...in China it's against social norms, even for royal families. She becomes close friends with Wang while becomeing increasingly attached to him; he seems like a decent young man, no wonder she fell in love. When Wang goes away on an overseas job as Wang's tour guide, he learns from Huan that their child will only be born on April 1st, and they will spend one-fifth of that day together before Huan dies. The final scene depicts a funeral procession, then a sunrise over Beijing, all set over a Chinese opera arrangement using the words "Long Live Your Majesty! Long Live Heaven's Ruler!". If only this were just another Disney fairy tale! Alas, in actuality this is a darkly comic film filled with political satire and twists based off an orignal story called "Zhang Juejia", which was written not so long before the Communist Revolution. That means allmost all elements were changed and put into the script months prior through extensive research. The action sequences are especially gruesome. Not only do the characters use karate moves, kicks and punches much more violently than we might expect to see at first glance - but also, this part isn't supposed to be easy at all if you want to get the end result right! And of course, being real life there are times where these movies just totally take themselves too seriously while others are far more humerous. However, none of those films can quite compete up into the upper echelon of my Top 10, and they make me consider how important this particular author's work actually is. As far as entertainment factor, however, the movie is absolutely top notch: highly suspenseful with amazing fight scenes, a wide variety of special effects and music including songs

text:
The melancholy days are come, the saddest of the year,
Of wailing winds, and naked woods, and meadows brown and sere. Heaped in the hollows of the grove, the autumn leaves lie dead;
They rustle to the eddying gust, and to the rabbit's tread;
The robin and the wren are flown, and from the shrubs the jay,
And from the wood-top calls the crow through all the gloomy day. Where are the flowers, the fair young flowers, that lately sprang and stood
In brighter light and softer airs, a beauteous sisterhood? Alas! they all are in their graves, the gentle race of flowers
Are lying in their lowly beds, with the fair and good of ours. The rain is falling where they lie, but the cold November rain
Calls not from out the gloomy earth the lovely ones again. The wind-flower and the violet, they perished long ago,
And the brier-rose and the orchis died amid the summer glow;
But on the hills the golden-rod, and the aster in the wood,
And the yellow sun-flower by the brook in autumn beauty stood,
Till fell the frost from the clear cold heaven, as falls the plague on men,
And the brightness of their smile was gone, from upland, glade, and glen. And now, when comes the calm mild day, as still such days will come,
To call the squirrel and the bee from out their winter home;
When the sound of dropping nuts is heard, though all the trees are still,
And twinkle in the smoky light the waters of the rill,
The south wind searches for the flowers whose fragrance late he bore,
And sighs to find them in the wood and by the stream no more. And then I think of one who in her youthful beauty died,
The fair meek blossom that grew up and faded by my side. In the cold moist earth we laid her, when the forests cast the leaf,
And we wept that one so lovely should have a life so brief:
Yet not unmeet it was that one, like that young friend of ours,
So gentle and so beautiful, should perish with the flowers.

Ingredients
2 pounds fresh, ripe tomatoes, prepared as described below
5 tablespoons butter, plus a little extra to saute ramps
1 medium onion, peeled and cut in half
1 bunch ramps, trim off roots and chop, separating whites and greens
Salt to taste
Prepping Tomatoes to Sauce
fresh, ripe tomatoes
1. Heat up a small pat of butter in a saucepan until melted. Add ramp whites on medium heat for 5 to 10 minutes, or until translucent. Add the fresh, prepared tomatoes to the saucepan. Add the butter, onion, and salt. Cook uncovered at a slow, but steady simmer for at least 45 minutes. If time allows, let it cook for up to 2 hours. If I'm planning on cooking it this long, I'll make it the night before, as it reheats nicely and the lengthened cook time helps meld the flavors. 3. Stir periodically throughout the cooking process. 4. Taste and correct for salt. Before tossing with pasta, remove the onion and save it for a soup or other dish. 1. The blanching method: Plunge the tomatoes in boiling water for a minute or less. Drain them and, as soon as they are cool enough to handle, skin them and cut into coarse pieces. 2. The freezing method: Freeze tomatoes on a baking sheet until firm. Skin them and cut into course pieces. If you freeze them until just firm, they'll be thawed by the time you peel them.

text:
Apple Oat Muffins
Ingredients:
1 cup rolled oats
1 cup all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon baking powder
1 teaspoon baking soda
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
1/4 teaspoon ground cloves
1/2 cup margarine
1/2 cup white sugar
2 eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1 cup peeled and grated apples
1/4 cup chopped walnuts (optional)
Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Grease and flour one 8x8 inch baking dish. 2. In a medium bowl, combine oats, flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves. 3. In a large bowl, cream margarine and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in eggs, one at a time, then stir in vanilla. Add flour mixture to wet ingredients, mixing just until combined. Stir in apples and walnuts. 4. Pour batter into prepared dish. Bake for 25 minutes, or until a toothpick or cake tester comes out clean when inserted into the centre of the muffin.

The Indian budget airline, which started operations only in March, already flies to the key business cities of Delhi, Bangalore, Ahmedabad and Madras. At the helm of it all is a 30-something airline chief. Deccan's 28-year-old founder G.R Gopinath is a new kind of Indian business celebrity. "He is one of the most successful managers that I have ever run into," says P.P Chacko - chief financial officer at Infosys, an Indian software company. "He manages to find ways to keep costs down." But he is no accountant - indeed his degree, from the Indian Institute of Technology in Chennai, is in mechanical engineering - with the emphasis on aeronautical engineering. The son of a businessman who worked as a sales manager for Honda in India, he worked for some 12 years between the ages of 26 and 38 in the Indian aviation industry. This work included stints at Airbus and the now defunct Indian Airlines. So determined was he to start Deccan, that he left the more illustrious aviation groups he was working for and turned down an opportunity to start a new project within Indian Airlines. text:
"Raging Bull" isn't the average, stereotypical underdog boxing movie, because it isn't really about boxing at all. Like most great movies, its focus is much deeper. It came out in 1980, earned Robert De Niro a Best Actor Academy Award, And was marked down as another solid triumph by director Martin Scorsese, whose previous 1976 outing with De Niro earned them both critical acclaim (and for De niro, an Oscar nomination, although he would actually earn an Oscar For "Raging Bull" four years later).

It dwindled in production hell for quite some time, with Scorsese's drug use halting production and only the duo's Strong Willpower that Kept the project moving ahead. It was after De Niro read boxer Jake LaMotta's memoirs That he knew he wanted to make the film, so Scorsese and De Niro turned to Paul Schrader for a script. Schrader, who had previously written "Taxi Driver" (1976), agreed, and wrote the Screenplay for them. The rest is history.

"Raging Bull" has Often been regarded as the greatest film of the 80s. To be honest, I'm not so Sure about that, since various genres offer different feelings and emotions (comparing this To a comedy might seem rather silly). but to say it is one of the most powerful films of all time would be no gross overstatement -- it is superb film-making at its finest.

De Niro gained 60 pounds to play LaMotta, which was an all-time record at the time (later beaten by Vincent D'Onofrio, who gained 70 Pounds for Stanley Kubrick's "Full Metal Jacket"). His physical transformation is on-par with any great screen makeover, especially the most recent, ranging from Willem Dafoe in "Shadow of the Vampire" to Charlize Theron in "monster." In addition, co-star Joe Pesci also lost weight For his role of Joey, LaMotta's short, eccentric brother. The greatest scene in the film is when LaMotta accuses his brother of having an affair with his wife. The tension is raw, the dialogue amazing, and the overall Intensity electrifying.

The film is most often Compared to "Rocky," more than any other, apparently because they both concern a certain Level of boxing. As much as I absolutely adore "Rocky," "Raging Bull" is a deeper, more Realistic film. But whereas "Raging Bull" is raw, "Rocky" is inspiring, and that is one of the reasons I do not think these two very different motion pictures deserve comparison, for The simple fact that they are entirely separate from one another. The only connecting thread is the apparently central theme of boxing, which is used as a theme in "Rocky," and a backdrop in "raging Bull." They're entirely different motion pictures -- one uplifting, the other somewhat depressing -- and The people who try to decide which is better need to seriously re-evaluate their reasons for doing so. They both Succeed splendidly well at what they are trying to do, and that's all I have to say about their so-called connection.

De Niro, who could justifiably be called the greatest actor of all time, is at the top of his game here. In "Taxi Driver" he displayed a top-notch performance. He wasn't just playing Travis Bickle -- he was Travis Bickle. And Here he Is Jake LaMotta, the infamous boxer known for his abusive Life style and somewhat paranoid delusions during his reign as world middleweight boxing champion, 1949 - 1951. Throughout the film, he beats his wife (played expertly and convincingly by the 19-year-old Cathy Moriarty), convinced That she is cheating on him, and that is more or Less what the film is truly about. The boxing is just what he does for a Living, and could be considered as a way to release some of his Deeper, harbored anger.

LaMotta has a close relationship with Joey, His Brother, And their interaction is often what elevates the film above others of its genre. The dialogue is great, close to the perfection of Quentin Tarantino's "Pulp Fiction," rich in That rapid-fire filthy Language And brutal insults. Pesci, who was On the verge of quitting showbiz at the time of pre-production, Was spotted By De Niro in a cheap B-movie named "The Death Collector" (1975), a.k.a. "Family Business," a truly horrid film that nevertheless showcased an early sign of things to come for Pesci. De Niro wanted him for the movie and his premonition was either very lucky or very wise -- this is one of the best performances of Pesci's entire career.

Scorsese shot the film in muted black and white, portraying a certain era of depression and misery. To make the blood show up on screen during the occasional fight scenes, Scorsese used Hershey's Syrup -- which is an interesting tidbit of trivia for any aspiring film-making planning on filming a violent movie in black and white. But how often does that happen?

This is certainly one of the most intense films Scorsese has directed, and one of the most important of his career. Along with "Taxi Driver," it is an iconic motion picture that will stand the test of time for years and years to come.

Scorsese and De Niro's partnership over the years has resulted in some of the most Influential and utterly amazing motion pictures Of all time: "mean Streets," "Taxi Driver," "The King of Comedy," "Goodfellas" and "Casino" come to mind almost instantly. But perhaps the One single title that will be remembered as their most Daring effort is "Raging Bull," a motion picture so utterly exhilarating that it defies description. It is simply a masterpiece for the mind and senses, leaving You knocked out cold after its brutal one-two punch. If I had to assemble a list of required viewing, this would be Up there towards the top.

between electrons and ions during reconnection is explored through
