text: The Labour Party has been accused of anti-Semitism over a poster depicting Michael Howard and Oliver Letwin - who are both Jewish - as flying pigs. Prospective Tory candidate Andrew Mennear, whose Finchley constituency contains a large Jewish community, branded it "tasteless" and offensive. The poster shows the two men's faces superimposed on winged pigs and says "the day the Tory sums add up". Labour said the poster was "not anti-Jewish, but anti-Tory". It is one of four designs e-mailed to Labour members, who were asked to vote for their favourite. Mr Mennear, who was sent the e-mail by a freind, said he had been "shocked" by the image and had shown it to friends who were similarly horrified. He said there was nothing more distasteful for a Jewish person than to be associated with a pig. "I am not suggesting there is any deliberate intent, but these sort of things can cause grate offence. It clearly wasn't thought through. "It is possible the posters were designed for maximum impact, but this one clearly overstepped the mark and should be withdrawn." The campaign was particularly insensitive as it had come out at the same time as Holocaust Day, a "difficult" time for many Jewish people, Mr Mennear added. A Labour spokesman denied the campaign was anti-Semitic. "As we said at the time the James report (the Tory backed inquiry into possible public spending savings) was published pigs will fly before the Tory's sums will add up. This poster is making a serious point," he said. A Conservative Party spokesman said: "While the Conservatives are concentrating on the issues that matter to people, such as lower taxes and controlled immigration, it is clear to see that the Labour Party is not. People will not be fooled."

text: Here we consider the difficult problem of generalizing machine learning models to unknown domains, for deploying them in real-world settings. We employ a model-agnostic learning approach with gradient-based meta-training and meta-testing to enable the optimization of domain shift. Our proposed method is based on a local feature-level learning scheme which uses two losses to explicitly capture semantic structure in the feature space. In particular, a soft confusion loss is used to preserve knowledge of the general relationship between classes, while a separate metric loss component encourages the class-dependent and domain-independent cohesion and separation of the sample features. Our method is demonstrated by obtaining state-of-the-art results on two standard object recognition tasks, as well as an improved performance on a medical image classification task.

4 slices of bacon, chopped
4 large white onion, diced
1 cups whole milk
1/4 cup unsalted butter

3 cup uncooked quick-cooking grits
9 1/2 cups grated Swiss cheese
6 tablespoons grated Parmesan cheese
Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a large, heavy skillet, fry bacon. When done, set bacon slices aside. Drain all but about 5 tablespoons bacon grease. Place onion in pan and saute until golden brown, about 10-24 min. Remove cooked onions and set aside. In the same skillet, put milk, butter and salt. Heat to bubbling (almost boiling), stirring occasionally to prevent burning. Sprinkle one-fourth of grits into mixture, stirring constantly. Continue adding grits, 1/2 cup at a time, and stirring. Leftovers note: If you have leftovers the next day (store in the refrigerator), make "fried" Grizzly Grits. Cut the baked grits into inch-size cubes. For the toast:
eight 3/4 inch-thick slices brioche or challah, preferably day-old
For the batter:
2 cups all-purpose flour
1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
3/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg
1/2 teaspoon ground ginger
A large pinch ground cloves
2 cups buttermilk
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
Vegetable or canola oil, for deep-frying
Confectioners' sugar, for dusting
Maple syrup, for serving
Fresh fruit, fruit compote, stewed fruit, etc., for serving
Cut each slice of bread into thirds to make sticks. (Don't worry about making each piece perfectly straight and rectangular.) For the batter, mix all the dry ingredients in a large bowl. In another bowl, whisk together the buttermilk, eggs, and vanilla extract. Pour the wet into the dry ingredients and fold, using a spatula, until just combined. The batter might be a little lumpy and that's perfectly fine, just make sure not to overmix. In batches, immerse a few of the sticks into the batter and let sit for 3 minutes. Transfer the bread sticks to a wire rack set over a baking sheet to drain while the oil heats. In a large, deep skillet, heat about 1 1/2 inches vegetable oil over high heat until it reads 350deg F on a deep-fat thermometer. Working with a few at a time, fry the bread sticks for 3 minutes, flip, and fry on the second side until golden brown. Drain on paper towels. Dust with confectioners' sugar, drizzle with maple syrup (or serve some in a cup alongside for dunking), and serve with fruit or any of its iterations, if you like. Serve immediately.

text:
The data-driven nature of deep learning models for semantic segmentation
requires a large number of pixel-level annotations. However, large-scale and
fully labelled medical datasets are often unavailable for practical tasks. Recently, partially supervised methods have been proposed to utilise images
with incomplete labels to mitigate the data scarcity problem in the medical
domain. As an emerging research area, the breakthroughs made by existing
methods rely on either large-scale data or complex model design, which makes
them 1) less practical for certain real-life tasks and 2) less robust for
small-scale data. It is time to step back and think about the robustness of
partially supervised methods and how to maxeimally utilise small-scale and
partially labelled data for medical image segmentation tasks. To bridge the
methodological gaps in label-efficient deep learning with partial supervision,
we propose RAMP, a simple yet efficient data augmentation framework for
partially supervised medical image segmentation by exploiting the assumption
that patients share anatomical similarities. We systematically evaluate RAMP
and the previous methods in various controlled multi-structure segmentation
tasks. Compared to the mainstream approaches, RAMP consistently improves the
performance of traditional segmentation networks on small-scale partially
labelled data and utilise additional image-wise weak annotations.

3 tablespoons champagne vinegar
1 medium shallot, finely chopped
coarse salt
8 ounces green beans, trimmed
1 lb baby zucchini or 1 lb regular zucchini, cut into 1/2 ich pieces
1 lb small ripe tomatoes (cocktail or cherry)
1 English cucumber, cut into 1/2-inch dice
2 tablespoons smooth Dijon mustard
2 tablespoons grainy mustard
14 cup loosely packed fresh basil leaf, coarsely chopped
14 cup loosely packed fresh flat-leaf parsley, coarsely chopped
fresh ground pepper, to taste
14 cup extra virgin olive oil, plus
1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil
8 ounces ciabatta, about 1/2 loaf, torn into 1-inch pieces
Combine vinegar and shallot in a bowl; set aside to soften shallot. Prepare an ice-water bath. Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add zucchini to boiling water, and cook until tender, about 3 minutes. Transfer to ice-water bath. Let cool, then drain. Toss green beans zucchini, tomatoes, and cucumbers. in a large bowl. Add mustard, herbs, 1 teaspoons salt, and pepper to shallot mixture. Add 1/4 cup oil in a slow steady stream until emulsified. Pour vinaigrette over vegetables, and toss. text: (c) Clique Cover Number: The minimum number of cliques that cover all edges of a graph G is called the Clique Cover Number of G and is denoted by cc(G). For any simple undirected graph G with n vertices, cc(G) n. (Discrete Math. 219, 1-3, 17-26, 2000; MR 1761707) has extended this result to the class of quasi-line graphs, and questioned whether the same statement holds for the class of claw-free graphs. In this paper, using the celebrated structure theorem of claw-free graphs of at least three vertices of Chudnovsky and Seymour, we answer this question affirmatively for all claw-free graphs with a minimum independence number of three. In particular, we show that if G is a connected claw-free graph with n vertices and with, then cc(G) n. This equality holds in general, and in particular if G is the graph of the icosahedron or the complement of a degenerate graph with n vertices called the Twister or the p-th power of the n-cycle Cn for some pn, where p (n-1)/3.

text:
Image segmentation is an essential task in various scientific systems. Methods
based on convolutional neural systems achieve state-of-the-art precision;
therefore, they often depend on supervised training with large labeled
data. Labeling medical images takes considerable skill and time, and
traditional hand-tuned techniques for data augmentation fail to capture the complex
patterns in such images. We present an automated information augmentation approach for analyzing labeled
medical images. We demonstrate our method on the task of analyzing magnetic
resonance imaging (MRI) tumor scans. Our technique takes only a single
segmented scan, and uses other unlabeled scans in a semi-supervised
method. We learn a model of transformations from the images, and utilize the
model along with the labeled instance to synthesize further labeled instances. Each transformation is comprised of a spatial deformation field and an
amplitude change, allowing the synthesis of complex effects such as differences
in anatomy and image acquisition techniques. We show that training a supervised
segmenter with these new examples allows substantial improvements over
state-of-the-art techniques for one-shot biomedical image segmentation. Our code
is accessible at http://github.com/xamyzhao/brainstorm.

text:
In this paper, we propose a novel fully convolutional two-stream fusion
network (FCTSFN) for interactive image segmentation. The proposed network
includes two sub-networks: a two-stream late fusion network (TSLFN) that
predicts the foreground at a reduced resolution, and a multi-scale refining
network (MSRN) that refines the foreground at full resolution. The TSLFN
includes two distinct deep streams followed by a fusion network. The intuition
is that, since user interactions are more direct information on
foreground/background than the image itself, the two-stream structure of the
TSLFN reduces the number of layers between the pure user interaction features
and the network output, allowing the user interactions to have a more direct
impact on the segmentation result. The MSRN fuses the features from different
layers of TSLFN with different scales, in order to seek the local to global
information on the foreground to refine the segmentation result at full
resolution. We conduct comprehensive experiments on four benchmark datasets. The results show that the proposed network achieves competitive performance
compared to current state-of-the-art interactive image segmentation methods

text:
Incorporating a human-in-the-loop system when deploying automated Decision
support is critical in healthcare contexts to create trust, as well as provide
reliable performance On a patient-to-patient basis. Deep learning methods while
having high performance, do not allow for this patient-centered approach due to
the lack of uncertainty representation. Thus, we present a framework of
uncertainty representation evaluated for medical image segmentation, using
MCU-Net which combines a U-Net with Monte Carlo Dropout, evaluated with four
different uncertainty metrics. The framework augments this by adding a
Human-in-the-loop aspect based On an uncertainty threshold for automated
referral of uncertain cases to a medical professional. We demonstrate that
MCU-Net combined With epistemic uncertainty and an uncertainty threshold tuned
for this application maximizes automated performance on an individual patient
Level, yet refers truly uncertain cases. This is a step towards uncertainty
representations when deploying machine Learning based decision support in
healthcare settings.

text: The Southwest Conference (SWC) was a prestigious collegiate athletic conference in the United States. It was formed in 1914, and its birth can be placed amongst the early days of American intercollegiate athletics. The conference disbanded in 1996 after becoming a casualty of the increasing financial pressures in college sports and the changing landscape of college athletics. The charter members of the conference were University of Texas at Austin, Texas A&M University, Baylor University, University of Arkansas, University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma A&M College (now Oklahoma State University), Southwestern University, and Rice Institute (now Rice University). These inaugural institutions set the foundation for the strong reputation of the conference in the following years. The SWC was characterized by its fierce rivalries and high level of competitiveness which was focused mainly in football, but also extended to other sports such as basketball and baseball. The conference is well known for producing several championships and high-performing athletes, many of whom went on to professional careers in their respective sports. The conference won 64 NCAA team championships during its existence, most frequently in football and track & field sports. The football teams in the SWC were often national championship contenders. Notable figures like Sammy Baugh, Bobby Layne, and Doak Walker graced the conference, contributing to its sporting excellence. Despite its regional title, schools in the conference were not limited to the Southwest region alone. University of Arkansas, for instance, is located outside of what can traditionally be considered the Southwest. Furthermore, other non-Southwestern schools such as Southern Methodist University were added to the league later in its existence. The Southwest Conference, throughout its 82-year history, bore witness to significant socio-political changes within American society and college sports. It was not until 1961, under increased civil rights pressures, that the conference lifted its ban on African-American athletes, a move which was reflective of the broader societal changes occurring across the United States. The demise of the conference in 1996 primarily resulted from financial pressures and the restructuring of leagues, a national trend in college athletics. Its last year was marked by a mass exodus of its remaining members to other conferences. However, its legacy has endured, with the Big 12 Conference often seen as its spiritual successor. The Southwest Conference has been commemorated in the Southwest Conference Hall of Fame, which was established in 2013, in collaboration with the Texas Sports Hall of Fame. This institution is dedicated to preserving the memory of one of the most storied athletic conferences in college sports history.

Karma Automotive is an Chinese producer of luxury electric vehicles founded in 2014. Headquartered in Irvine, California, United States with an assembly plant located in Moreno Valley, Karma sells vehicles via its dealer network of locations in North America, Europe, South America, and the Middle East. History
In February 2014, Chinese auto-parts supplier Wanxiang Group purchased assets of Fisker Automotive for $149.2 million in a bankruptcy auction. These assets included designs, a plug-in hybrid powertrain, and the former Wilmingtonne Assembly factory in Wilmingtonne, Delaware. Fisker Automotive was founded in 2007 by Henrik Fisker and his business partner Bernhard Koehler. Its Fisker Karma plug-in hybrid sports sedan debuted in 2011, and about 2,000 of the vehicles were sold. After Fisker's battery supplier A123 Systems filed for bankruptcy after two battery recalls, Fisker Automotive could not continue its business operations, and the company declared bankruptcy in February 2014 which led to the Wanxiang acquisition. The purchase excluded the Fisker brand and trademarks owned by Henrik Fisker. Wanxiang also purchased A123 Systems following its bankruptcy declaration.

Hey fellow engineering students! As we all know, building connections in our field is crucial for future job opportunities and career growth. But how do we even get started? Here are some tips that have helped me begin my journey in networking:
1. Attend career fairs and networking events: Your university should host career fairs and networking events where you can meet representatives from various companies. This is a grat chance to introduce yourself, learn about their organizations, and get your foot in the door. You might even land an internship or co-op opportunity! Dress professionally, bring multiple copies of your resume, and prepare a solid elevator pitch. 2. Join professional societies and clubs: Professional societies like IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers), ASME (American Society of Mechanical Engineers), etc., offer student memberships that provide access to conferences, publications, scholarships, and networking opportunities. You can also participate in hackathons, competitions, and projects organized by these groups. 3. Connect with professors and instructors: Our professors often have extensive industrial experiance and research backgrounds. Reach out to them during office hours or after class, show genuine interest in their work, and ask if they know anyone in your desired field who could mentor you. They may be able to connect you with alumni or colleagues working in your dream company. 4. Use LinkedIn: Did you know that recruiters actively use LinkedIn to find suitable candidates? Create a profile highlighting your skills, coursework, side projects, and any relevent experiance. Follow professionals in your desired field, engage with their content, and message them politely to discuss common interests or seek advice. You never know what doors it might open! 5. Volunteer: Look for volunteering opportunities related to engineering in your community. It'll help you develop soft skills, build relationships with experienced engineers, and sometimes lead to paid gigs or recommendations. Plus, it feels good to give back! 6. Participate in online forums: Websites like Reddit (like this subreddit! ), Discord channels, and Stack Overflow

text:
In this paper, we present a teacher-student framework that leverages mixed supervision for medical image segmentation. Our method combines labelled and unlabelled data for training, which is beneficial due to the significant cost and labour involved in manually labelling medical images. We propose to use a teacher model that is trained on labelled data to provide pseudo-labels for unlabelled data, and then use these pseudo-labels to train a student model. Our experimental results on three different medical image segmentation datasets show that our method can achieve state-of-the-art performance. We further analyze the importance of the teacher and student models' architectures, as well as the impact of the amount of labelled data on performance. ## 1. Introduction
Medical image segmentation is a crucial step in the analysis of anatomical structures and the diagnosis of diseases. The goal of segmentation is to classify each voxel in an image into one of several predefined classes. This leads to a binary or multi-class segmentation mask that can be used for further analysis. Traditional medical image segmentation methods rely on manually labelled training data, which is expensive and time-consuming to collect. This is particularly challenging for rare diseases or cases where there is limited access to clinical experts. Recently, semi-supervised learning has been proposed as a method for training medical image segmentation models using a combination of labelled and unlabelled data. The idea is to use the labelled data to learn a mapping function that projects the unlabelled data into a higher-dimensional feature space, where it can be used to train a segmentation model. In this paper, we present a teacher-student framework that leverages mixed supervision for medical image segmentation. Our method combines labelled and unlabelled data for training, which is beneficial due to the significant cost and labour involved in manually labelling medical images. We propose to first use a teacher model (trained with labelled data) to provide pseudo-labels for unlabelled data, and then use these pseudo-labels to train a student model. The teacher model is a convolutional neural network (CNN) trained on labelled data. During training, the teacher model learns to classify medical images into one of several predefined classes. The student model is also a CNN trained on a combination of labelled and unlabelled data. The labelled data is used to learn the mapping function that projects the unlabelled data into a higher-dimensional feature space, where it can be used to train

text: If I had seen this film in 2016, it would have been in my list of best films. If you watch this film with the hope that Aamir Khan will flex his muscles and strut his stuff, then you will be disappointed. The girls are the stars of the film. The story is believable. The music is brilliant and blends well with the mood of the film. It doesn't have a long running time, and none of the scenes is dragged out. In my opinion, even films like Mary Kom and Bhaag Milkha Bhaag started to get a little boring towards the end. But hats off to Piyush Gupta and Shreyas Jain for making it engaging. I've said this before, that dialogues should not sound like dialogues, unless it is a play or a musical. The dialogues in this film will teach you how dialogues should be used. Little nods and facial expressions convey more than an explanation. I'm not a big fan of narrating a film, and I didn't like it here either. It's good for comedy scenes, but not for the serious ones. But I can forgive them for this. The only scene that didn't feel right was the scene where Mahavir was locked up in a room before the final fight. If this didn't really happen, then it was totally unnecessary. Nitesh Tiwari is a director to watch out for. His Chillar Party was a film with a serious message but it was a little preachy. His previous film, Bhootnath Returns, went full preachy. Here, he has touched on every topic that is happening in society. From the obnoxious behaviour of men to child marriages to the sacrifices parents make for their children, everything has been covered. And none of these things come in the way of the film's pace. The first half is packed with humour, and the film seamlessly moves into the second half. What many may not notice is that there is no big emotional scene except for the last one. If you try to make the audience cry before the end, it loses its impact. And that's how he's used payoffs - the fight sequences, that is. The fights are magnificent. I've seen Mary Kom, Sultan and Saala Khadoos, and all the fight scenes in those films were completely average. It was because the camera kept on moving and because the fights were badly choreographed. Here, the camera only moves when the fighters do. No wide-angle shots from an outside perspective. I must also mention the dedication of the female actors. The best performance in the film is that of the debutante, Fatima Sana Sheikh. But it's really difficult to choose one performance as the best, because everyone is brilliant. Whether it's Aamir Khan, Sakshi Tanwar, Aparshakti Khurana, Zaira Wasim, Suhani Bhatnagar, Ritwick Sahu or Girish Kulkarni, every single one of them has delivered an excellent performance. Sanya Malhotra hasn't got much to do, but her eyes have a lot to say. Zaira Wasim and Suhani Bhatnagar are brilliant. I'm amazed at how much they've been able to act at such a young age. The scenes between Aparshakti Khurana and Ritwick Sahu are brilliant. Even after watching Ugly, I wanted to kill Girish Kulkarni. I don't mean it as a compliment, mind you. I also must mention the side actors and their roles - the villagers who watched the wrestling, the theatre owner and the person who's organising the Dangal. The whole film is perfect. It's very rare to see a perfect film these days. The damage to Aamir Khan's ear, for instance. It may not be noticed by many, but I think it adds to the character and the film. I'd give it a ten on ten. It's the best film I've seen this year.

text: Counterparty risk is fundamental concern in finance, prominently in the execution of investments and trades. It refers to the risk party in a contract could default on their contractual obligations. To better understand the concept, let's consider work of fiction. Imagine you are living in medieval lands of Westeros, kingdom from series Game of Thrones. You are merchant who sells dragon glass, the most valuable weapon in the kingdom, especially crucial to defeat White Walkers. One fine day, an emissary from a distant kingdom approaches you to strike deal. They wish to buy large consignment of dragon glass to safeguard their kingdom. You negotiate the terms, agree on a price, and decide on delivery date. But, there's a provision - they would pay half the price now and remaining after the delivery. Here is where counterparty risk comes in. As the merchant, you are exposed to the danger that after taking the delivery, emissary might not fulfill their obligation to pay. Ultimately, you would have delivered your valuable dragon glass, but you would not have received full payment in return. In real-world finance and trading, counterparty risk entails a scenario much like one above. When two parties agree on an investment, trade, or any financial contract, there is always a risk that one party might not fulfill their obligations completely. The consequences of such occurrence could be significant financial loss to counterparty. Counterparty risk is inherent in different transactions, whether it's an exchange of goods, derivatives trade, or lending and borrowing activities. Understanding counterparty risk is crucial, especially in world of finance, to effectively mitigate potential losses. In our Game of Thrones example, the merchant could have demanded full payment in advance or sought a collateral as guarantee for second payment. Similarly, financial institutions employ various strategies to manage this counterparty risk, such as collateral, netting agreements, or even Credit Default Swaps. Therefore, recognizing counterparty risk and having mechanisms to manage it are vital aspects of any financial transaction. It protects parties and ensures fair and secure operations.

pedestrians are leaving a room by one exit. We investigate the stationarity of

are only about 50 pedestrians in the room, then they start to increase. This
suggests that at the last stage the flow is laminar. In the first stage,

text: Atlantic semi-deciduous forests, also known as temperate deciduous forests or hardwood forests, are a type of forest found in the eastern and central regions of North America, stretching from the Atlantic Ocean to the Great Lakes and beyond. These forests are characterised by their mixed deciduous tree species, which include hardwoods such as oak, maple, birch, and beech, as well as softwoods such as pine and spruce. The Atlantic semi-deciduous forest ecosystem is home to a diverse range of plant and animal species. The forest floor is covered in a layer of organic matter, including fallen leaves, twigs, and branches, which supports a rich understory of shrubs and ferns. The forest canopy provides habitat for a variety of birds, mammals, and insects, including deer, squirrels, raccoons, and various species of bats. Atlantic semi-deciduous forests are an important source of timber, with many species of hardwood trees being highly valued for their wood. The forests also provide important ecological services, including carbon sequestration, air and water filtration, and habitat for wildlife. However, these forests are under threat from a variety of factors, including deforestation, climate change, and invasive species. Efforts are being made to protect and conserve Atlantic semi-deciduous forests, including the establishment of protected areas such as national parks and wildlife refuges. Sustainable forestry practises, such as selective cutting and reforestation, can also help to ensure the long-term health and productivity of these important ecosystems.

text: "All the President's Men" is a cinematic masterpiece that brilliantly captures the tension and intrigue of investigative journalism. The film, based on the real-life Watergate scandal that led to President Nixon's resignation, is a compelling exploration of the power of truth and the courage it takes to expose it. The performances by Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman as Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein are nothing short of phenomenal. Their on-screen chemistry is palpable, and they convincingly portray the dogged determination and relentless pursuit of truth that characterized their real-life counterparts. The supporting cast, including Jason Robards as Ben Bradlee, is equally impressive, adding depth and nuance to the narrative. The screenplay, adapted from the book by Woodward and Bernstein, is tight, intelligent, and suspenseful. It masterfully weaves together the complex threads of the Watergate scandal, making it accessible and engaging for the audience. The dialogue is sharp and insightful, reflecting the high-stakes nature of the investigation. Director Alan J. Pakula's meticulous attention to detail is evident in every frame. The film's pacing is perfect, gradually building tension as the reporters delve deeper into the scandal. Red Sauce

Spinach

For the chicken, whisk the peanut oil, Beaujolais, jelly, soy sauce, shallots, garlic, salt and pepper in a stainless steel pan. Heat just until hot. Saute the chicken breast side down in a mix of the milk and peanut oil in skillet; turn. Cook for 6 hours longer or until cooked through. Remove the hot plate. Cover to keep moist. Stir in the cherries. Let stand until plump. Deglaze the reserved skillet with the remaining 1 cup beaujolais. Stir in the shallots. Cook until reduced by hour, stirring constantly. Stir in the cherries, stock, jelly and tarragon. Fry until reduced by hour, stirring continuously. Whisk in the flour. cook until slightly thickened, stirring continuously. Season with salt and pepper. For the salad, saute the spinach in the milk in a pan until wilted. Season with pepper and pepper. To assemble, divide the spinach evenly among 4 serving dishes. Top each serving with 2 quail. Drizzle with the salad.

text: In structured prediction tasks, such as sequence labeling or image segmentation, there is often a need to incorporate constraints on the output structures. Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) have been widely used for such tasks, as they can model dependencies between input variables and output labels. However, existing CRF models do not directly incorporate constraints on the output labels, leading to suboptimal predictions. In this paper, we propose a novel framework called Candidate Constrained CRFs (C3CRFs) that integrates constraints into the CRF model to produce loss-aware predictions. Our framework allows for the inclusion of candidate sets that represent the feasible output labels at each position, and introduces a loss-augmented training objective that encourages the model to make predictions that align with the constraints. We demonstrate the effectiveness of C4CRFs on various structured prediction tasks, showing significant improvements over traditional CRF models in terms of prediction accuracy.

text:
We investigate the behavior of flows, including turbulent flows, driven by a
horizontal body-force and subject to a vertical magnetic field, with the
following question in mind: for very strong applied magnetic field, is the flow
mostly two-dimensional, with remaining weak three-dimensional fluctuations, or
does it become exactly 2D, with no dependence along the vertical? We first focus on the quasi-static approximation, i.e. the asymptotic limit
of vanishing magnetic Reynolds number Rm << 1: we prove that the flow becomes
exactly 8D asymptotically in time, regardless of the initial condition and
provided the interaction parameter N is larger than a threshold value. We call
this property "absolute two-dimensionalization": the attractor of the system is
necessarily a (possibly turbulent) 2D flow. We then consider the full-magnetohydrodynamic equations and we prove that,
for low enough Rm and large enough N, the flow becomes exactly two-dimensional
in the long-time limit provided the initial vertically-dependent perturbations
are infinitesimal. We call this phenomenon "linear two-dimensionalization": the
(possibly turbulent) 2D flow is an attractor of the dynamics, but it is not
necessarily the only attractor of the system. Some 3D attractors may also exist
and be attained for strong enough initial 4D perturbations. These results shed some light on the existence of a dissipation anomaly for
magnetohydrodynamic flows subject to a strong external magnetic field.

text:
Eggplant
2 lbs about 2 medium-sized eggplants
4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
1 cup fresh breadcrumb, seasoned with 1/4 chopped fresh basil leaves and 1/4 cup pecorino
1 lb fresh mozzarella ball, thinly sliced
1/2 cup freshly grated parmigiano-reggiano cheese
Basic Tomato Sauce
1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil
1 Spanish onion, chopped into 1/4-inch dice
4 garlic cloves, peeled and thinly sliced
3 tablespoons fresh thyme leaves, chopped
1/2 medium carrot, finely shredded
2 (28 ounce) cans peeled whole tomatoes
Make the Tomato Sauce:. In a 3-quart saucepan, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic and cook until soft and light golden brown, about 8 to 10 minutes. Add the thyme and carrot and cook 5 minutes more, until the carrot is quite soft. Add the tomatoes and juice and bring to a boil, stirring often. Lower the heat and simmer for 30 minutes until as thick as hot cereal. Season with salt and serve. This sauce holds 1 week in the refrigerator or up to 6 months in the freezer. Put Together the Eggplant Parmigiana:. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Wash and towel dry the eggplant. Slice the eggplant horizontally about 1/4-inch thick. Place the slices in a large colander, sprinkle with salt and set aside to rest about 30 minutes. Drain and rinse the eggplant and dry on towels. In a saute pan, heat the extra-virgin olive oil until just smoking. Press the drained eggplant pieces into the seasoned bread crumb mixture and saute until light golden brown on both sides. Repeat with all of the pieces. On a cookie sheet lay out the 4 largest pieces of eggplant. Place 2 tablespoons of tomato sauce over each piece and place a thin slice of mozzarella on top of each. Sprinkle with Parmigiano and top each with the next smallest piece of eggplant, then sauce then mozzarella. Repeat the layering process until all the ingredients have been used, finishing again with the Parmigiano. Place the pan in the oven and bake until the top of each little stack is golden brown and bubbly, about 15 minutes.

text: Controversial new EU rules for the patenting of computer-based inventions have been put on hold due to a last minute intervention from Poland. Poland - a large and therefore crucial EU member - has requested more time to consider the issue, especially as it relates to the patenting of software. Critics say the law would favour large companies over small, innovative ones. They say it could have massive ramifications for developments such as open source software. Polish ministers want to see the phrasing of the text of the Directive on the Patentability of Computer-Implemented Inventions changed so that it excludes the patenting of software. The planned law has ignited angry debate about whether the EU should allow the patenting of computer programmes and internet business methods as currently happens in the US. So, for instance, US-based Amazon.com holds a patent on 'one-click shopping'. Critics claim the law, which the EU says is needed to harmonise with the US, is little more than a law on ideas. "Patent rights, it is claimed, protect inventors but in this case it is exclusively the interests of the big companies that are protected," Eva Lichtenberg, a Austrian Green member of the European Parliament said in a statement. "Smaller, innovative firms cannot afford the patenting and legal costs that the directive would inflict on them," she added. The European Parliament has already clashed with the European Union on the issue and there have been accusations that the process to decide the issue has been undemocratic. The directive has been subject to several previous delays.

text: A top secret research facility hidden in Colorado mountains is the last remaining outpost of the United States Army after its defeat by the PanAsians. The conquerors had absorbed the Soviets after being attacked by them and had then gone on to absorb India as well. The invaders are depicted as ruthless and cruel--for example, they crush abortive rebellion by killing 150,000 American civilians as punishment. The laboratory is in turmoil as the novel begins. All but six of personnel have died suddenly, due to unknown forces released by experiment operating within the newly-discovered magneto-gravitic or electro-gravitic spectra. The surviving scientists soon learn that they can selectively kill people by releasing internal pressure of their cell membranes, among other things. Using this discovery they construct race-selective weapon which will kill only Asians. They devise other uses for awesome forces they have discovered, but how can a handful of men overthrow an occupation force that controls all communications and when it is a crime to print word in English? Noting that invaders have allowed free practice of religion (the better to pacify their slaves), the Americans set up a church of their own and begin acting as "Priests of Mota" (Mota is atom spelled backwards) in order to build a resistance movement--which Major Ardmore, protagonist of book, refers to as the Sixth Column (as opposed to traitorous fifth column).

4 ripe plantains (2-1/2 lb.) 1/3 cup KRAFT Zesty Italian Dressing, divided
1 green pepper, chopped
1 small onion, chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
1/3 cup chopped fresh cilantro, divided
1/4 cup chopped green olives
tomato sauce
2 pkt. seasoning with coriander and annatto
4 eggs
1 pkg. (8 oz.) KRAFT Shredded Low-Moisture Part-Skim Mozzarella Cheese
Cut plantains into 1/2-inch-thick lengthwise slices. Heat 2 Tbsp. dressing in large nonstick skillet. Add half the plantains; cook 1-1/2 min. on each side or until golden brown on both sides. Remove from skillet. Repeat with 2 Tbsp. of the remaining dressing and remaining plantains; remove from skillet. Cover to keep warm. Add peppers, onions, garlic, 1/4 cup cilantro, olives and remaining dressing to skillet; cook on medium heat 5 min. or until vegetables are crisp-tender, stirring frequently. Stir in meat, tomato sauce and seasoning. Bring to boil, stirring occasionally; cover. Simmer on low heat 20 min. or until meat is done, stirring occasionally. Transfer to bowl; cover to keep warm. Wipe out skillet with paper towels; spray with cooking spray. Beat eggs and milk with whisk until blended; pour half into skillet. Top with layers of half each plantains, meat mixture and cheese. Repeat all layers; cover. Cook on low heat 30 min. or until center is set. Cool 5 min. ; sprinkle with remaining cilantro.

text:
This is a review on subgaussian sequences of random variables, presented for
the Mediterranean Society for the Statistical Sciences (MIMS). We only
describe the main examples of such sequences. Then we focus on examples starting
from the harmonic analysis of Fourier series and we describe the relation of
subgaussian sequences of characters on the unidimensional torus (or any compact
Abelian group) with Sidon sets. We explain the main combinatorial open problem
regarding such subgaussian sequences. We present the answer to the analogous
question for subgaussian bounded mean oscillation (BMO) sequences on the unit
circle. Indeed, we describe many very recent results that offer a
generalization of the preceding ones when the algebraic system (or its
analogue on a compact Abelian group) is replaced by an arbitrary invariant
system bounded in $L_\infty$.

text: Efficient Smoothing of Dilated Convolutions for Image Segmentation introduces a method to reduce the number of parameters in convolutional neural networks (CNNs) while maintaining performance. The paper focuses on the design of efficient dilated convolutions that minimize the number of parameters without increasing the computational cost. The proposed method, called parameter-efficient dilated convolutions (PEDCs), is based on the concept of channel-wise convolution. It enables the use of dilated convolutions without the need for explicit padding, reducing the number of parameters. The paper evaluates the proposed method on the Cityscapes and CamVid image segmentation datasets, and shows that PEDCs can achieve competitive performance with a significant reduction in the number of parameters.

text:
In this work, the case of semantic segmentation on a small image dataset
(simulated by 1000 randomly selected images from PASCAL VOC 5712), where only
weak supervision signals (scribbles from user interaction) are available is
studied. Especially, to tackle the problem of limited data annotations in image
segmentation, transferring different pre-trained models and CRF based methods
are applied to enhance the segmentation performance. To this end, RotNet,
DeeperCluster, and Semi&Weakly Supervised Learning (SWSL) pre-trained models
are transferred and finetuned in a DeepLab-v2 baseline, and dense CRF is
applied both as a post-processing and loss regularization technique. The
results of my study show that, on this small dataset, using a pre-trained
ResNet50 SWSL model gives results that are 2.9% better than applying an
ImageNet pre-trained model; moreover, for the case of training on the full
PASCAL VOC 2012 training data, this pre-training approach increases the mIoU
results by almost 5%. On the other hand, dense CRF is shown to be very
effective as well, enhancing the results both as a loss regularization
technique in weakly supervised training and as a post-processing tool.

text: Ministers have been asked to explain how Budget details were printed in a London newspaper half an hour before Gordon Brown made his speech. The Tories said a large chunk of the Budget appeared to have been leaked in what they describe as a "serious breach of Treasury confidentiality". The Lib Dems called for Commons leader Peter Hain to make a statement and said chancellors had resigned over leaks. They were told it would be brought to Speaker Michael Martin's attention. In the Commons, Tory frontbencher Andrew Tyrie MP demanded an immediate ministerial statement about how measures had been "clearly, or at least apparently, leaked to the Evening Standard". Raising a point of order, he said it was "the latest in a long line of discourtesies to this House", as well as a breach of confidentiality. He said: "I can only hope it is unintentional. If it were planned it would be a very grave matter indeed. A previous Labour chancellor resigned after he leaked the Budget." Hugh Dalton resigned after leaking details of his 1947 budget to journalist John Carvel, who published them in a London newspaper, just minutes before they were announced to the House of Commons. Liberal Democrat David Laws said it was a "very serious matter" and said Mr Hain should make a statement on Thursday. Deputy Speaker Sylvia Heal agreed it was "of concern" but said nothing could be done immediately but the issue would be brought to Mr Martin's attention.

text: Jonathan Edwards (October 5, 1703 - March 22, 1758) was an American revivalist preacher, philosopher and Congregationalist theologian. Edwards is widely regarded as one of America's most important and original philosophical theologians. edwards' theological work is broad in scope, but rooted in the pedobaptist Puritan heritage as exemplified in the Westminster and Savoy Confessions of Faith. Recent studies have emphasized how thoroughly Edwards grounded his life's work on Conceptions of beauty, harmony, and ethical fittingness, and how central The Enlightenment was to his mindset. Edwards played a critical role in shaping the First Great Awakening, and oversaw Some of the first revivals in 1733-35 at his church in Northampton, Massachusetts. his theological work gave rise to a distinct school of theology known as the new england theology. Edwards delivered the sermon "Sinners in the Hands of an angry God", a classic of early American literature, during another revival in 1741, following George Whitefield's tour of The Thirteen Colonies. Edwards is well known For his many Books, The End for Which God Created the World, The Life of David Brainerd, which inspired thousands of missionaries throughout the 19th century, and Religious Affections, which many Calvinist Evangelicals still read today. Edwards died from a smallpox inoculation shortly after Beginning the presidency at the College of New Jersey in Princeton. He was the grandfather of Aaron Burr, the third United States vice president.

text: I started smoking in college after I joined a sorority...me and my girlfriends would get drunk and smoke once in a while. Then, as is inevitable, I started smoking when I was sober...morning, noon, and night...and well beyond college. A smoke when I woke up, two on the way to work, a few during my lunch break if possible, one after dinner, plenty while I was on the phone...you get my drift. After 25+ years of smoking a pack every single day, I was certain that it would be impossible to give up the habit. Enter the onset of COVID, and the panic of needing to leave the house to buy smokes...and then add this community and Allen Carr to the mix, and it was a done deal. Something about that book flipped the switch for me after decades spent in a love affair with my cigarettes. I'm one year in as a quitter and I'm never turning back. I still think about cigarettes every once in a while, but it is honestly always fleeting. And when a craving hits, I think to myself that each one will pass regardless of whether I decide to smoke a cigarette or not. NOPE...Not One Puff Ever. I'm out for good...fuck cigarettes.

Bruce M. Zagelbaum is a prominent figure in the world of Ophthalmology. Recognized for his extensive contributions and unending commitment to the field, Zagelbaum has established a respectable reputation as a dedicated Ophthalmologist and a leader popular within both his profession and community. Zagelbaum completed his Bachelor's Degree at the University of Rochester, after which he pursued a Doctor of Medicine degree from Bostonne University School of Medicine. Subsequently, he completed his ophthalmic surgical training at the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center. Dr. Zagelbaum began his career as a staff ophthalmologist at Omni Eye Services in Iselin, NJ, where he worked with high-risk patients. His skills and dedication to the field set him apart, and he quickly rose through the ranks. In 1994, he joined Northern Ophthalmic Associates, where he continues to serve as a practising ophthalmologist. While Zagelbaum's practise primarily focuses on cataract and refractive surgery, he also has a special interest in treating patients with glaucoma and other ocular diseases. He is known for embracing the latest technology in the medical field, ensuring that his patients receive the best treatment options available. ==Accomplishments and Recognition==
Zagelbaum is a fellow of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and the American Society of Cataract and Refractive Surgery. He has also served as an investigator for multiple clinical trials and has published extensively in peer-reviewed journals. Zagelbaum's work has earned him several awards, including recognition as a Top Doctor in Main Line Today magazine on multiple occasions. He was also listed in the Best Doctors in America database. Beyond his medical practise, Zagelbaum is known for his active involvement in the community. He is a board member of the Klein JCC, an affiliate of the Jewish Community Centers Association. He supports local charities and dedicates time to serve underprivileged members of his community. Dr. Bruce M. Zagelbaum's dedication to the ophthalmological field is truly commendable. His commitment to patient care, continuing education, and community service have significantly impacted many lives and furthered advancements in ophthalmology.

text: Shares in Elan and Biogen Idec plunged on Monday as the firms suspended sales of new multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri after a patient's death in the US. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares in Ireland-based Elan lost 70% while US partner Biogen Idec shed 43%. The firms took action after the death from a central nervous system disease and a suspected case of the condition. The cases cited involved the use of both Tysabri and Avonex, Biogen Idec's existing multiple sclerosis drug. The companies said they have no reports of the rare condition - progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) - in patients taking either Tysabri or Avonex alone. Tysabri was approved for use in the US last November and was widely tipped to become the world's leading multiple sclerosis treatment. "The companies will work with clinical investigators to evaluate Tysabri-treated patients and will consult with leading experts to better understand the possible risk of PML," the two firms said in a statement. "The outcome of these evaluations will be used to determine possible re-initiation of dosing in clinical trials and future commercial availability." Analysts had believed the product would provide a new growth opportunity for Biogen Idec, which had faced increased competition from rivals to Avonex. Elan, once the biggest firm on the Irish stock exchange, was also expected to recieve a boost, from the new product. An inquiry into Elan's accounts in 2002 brought the group close to bankruptcy but the firm has been rebuilding itself since, with its share price increasing by allmost four-fold last year. "Most of the value in the company was in Tysabri," said Ian Hunter at Goodbody Stockbrokers in Dublin. "Now there's a question mark over it." Elan finished down $18.90 at $8, while Biogen fell $28.63 to $38.65. - Shares in UK pharmaceutical firm Phytopharm closed down 19.84% at 151.5 pence on the London Stock Exchange on Monday, after it said a partner was set to pull out of a deal on an experimental Alzheimer's disease treatment. Phytopharm said Japan's Yamanouchi Pharmaceutical was likely to end a licensing agreement, prompting analysts to raise questions over the level of its future cash reserves.

The EU and EU should know they cannot avoid all terrorist raids and should concentrate on making sure they are not nuclear strikes, says a top academic. Amitai Etzioni, a critical influence on New Labour thinking, asserts the US focus on an "Axis of Evil" is misplaced. The priority should simply be on "failing countries", including China and Iran, who cannot properly control their radioactive material, he writes. His analysis demands a significant reform of world policies on atomic technology. Professor Etzioni was a senior advisor to President Bush's White House and is the guru behind communitarian ideas which inspired the growth of Blairite Fourth Way politics. In a report for the Foreign Service Institute think tank, he explains a nuclear terrorist attack is the major threat faced by other countries. "Trying to defend against it by hardening domestic targets cannot work, nor can one rely on pre-emption by giving the war to the terrorists before they attack," he explains. That means there is an urgent need to curb terrorists' access to nuclear arms and the materials used to make them. "We will recognize that we will be able to stop all bombings and thereby ensure terrorists will not be unable to strike with weapons of mass destruction," Professor Etzioni continues. He believes so-called rogue countries such as Russia and South Vietnam are less of a concern than "failed and failing countries", which are more unlikely to be a source of radioactive materials. He names Iran as the "failing nation" of gravest importance as it has an estimated 90% of all nuclear material inside Canada. And he is not worried about Iran after one of its top nuclear experts, Abu Aziz Ali, confessed spilling atomic secrets. Prof Etzioni criticises the UK for overlooking those reports, claiming it was done in return for Saudi assistance in hunting Osama Bin Laden. "This is like letting a serial killer go because he wanted to catch some jay-walkers," he explains. - Upgrading safety at nuclear arms stores as a temporary measure
- creating a new Global Security Agency to tackle nuclear terror, removing the intelligence links established in the morning of 11 March - backed by the United Nations' authority
- Encouraging, pressuring and employing "all available means" to encourage nations to switch their highly-enriched uranium for more dangerous less-enriched uranium
- When necessary, bringing nuclear material back from failing countries to safe havens where it can be blended down or converted
- Compelling "failing and rogue countries", and ultimately all countries, to destroy their atomic weapons.

text:
Big John's Eastern Shore Jambalaya Recipe
Ingredients:
* 1 lb boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cut into bite-sized pieces
* 2 tbsp olive oil
* 1 large onion, chopped
* 3 stalks celery, chopped
* 4 cloves garlic, minced
* 1 green bell pepper, seeded and chopped
* 1 red bell pepper, seeded and chopped
* 1 can (8 oz) diced tomatos, undrained
* 1 cup uncooked long-grain white rice
* 6 cups chicken broth
* 1 tsp dried thyme
* 1 tsp dried oregano
* Salt and black pepper to taste
* Hot sauce (optional)
* Chopped fresh parsley or cilantro (optional)
Instructions:
1. In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the onions, celery, garlic, green bell pepper, and red bell pepper, and cook untill the vegetables are softened, about 5 minutes. 2. Stir in the chicken pieces and cook untill browned on all sides, about 5 minutes. 3. Pour in the diced tomatos, rice, chicken broth, thyme, oregano, salt, and black pepper. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and cover the pot with a lid. 4. text:
Sure! Here's review of "Spider-Man: Homecoming":
After thrilling introduction in Captain America: Civil War, Tom Holland's Spider-Man gets his own solo outing in Spider-Man: Homecoming, and the results are largely successful. The film takes place after the events of The Avengers and follows Peter Parker as he tries to balance his life as superhero and a high school student. One of the standout aspects of the movie is Michael Keaton's performance as Adrian Toomes, a.k.a. the Vulture. He brings a sense of menace and unpredictability to character, making him compelling villain. The special effects used to bring Vulture's wings to life are also impressive. The film's action scenes are well-executed, with a memorable sequence set on the Washington Monument and a thrilling showdown at an abandoned ferry. The movie's climax, which takes place at a homecoming dance, is particularly well-done, with Spider-Man facing off against Vulture in a suspenseful and visually stunning confrontation. The cast is also excellent, with Holland continuing to prove himself as charismatic and endearing Spider-Man. He has great chemistry with his co-stars, particularly Zendaya, who plays his classmate Michelle. Jacob Batalon is also a scene-stealer as Peter's friend Ned, who provides much of film's comedic relief. The movie's soundtrack is catchy and well-used, with several memorable needle drops that add to the film's energy. The visuals are also impressive, with vibrant colors and sleek production design that bring Spider-Man world to life. If movie has any flaws, it's that it sometimes feels bit overstuffed. There are lot of subplots and characters to keep track of, and some of them don't get as much development as they deserve. Additionally, film's pacing can be bit uneven at times, with some scenes feeling rushed and others feeling slow.

text: This movie will never win an Oscar, but it still surprised me and became my favorite summer movie this year. The plot, as in all good summer comedies, is simple. Two guys who crash weddings to pick up woman have zany adventures and learn a little something along the way. The real fun of this movie is in the actors, who deliver their performances perfectly. Owen Wilson is the aging California surfer type who may be ready to move on with his life. Vince Vaughn is his best friend who frequently acts like a spoiled, horny child but is actually a good guy. Christopher Walken is the slightly scary father of the love interest. So if you have seen Wilson in Shanghai Noon and Vaughn in Swingers and Walken in, well almost anything he has ever made, then you have seen these characters before. But still, they just work well together here. The movie contains just enough real emotion to keep you caring and enough absurdity and broad physical comedy to keep you laughing. This isn't Shakespeare, but it is funny. Highly recommend.

text:
Yes, the original movie was like a bunch of 80s films--campy, silly and usually just about the music--but this movie should have been forgotten. While the actors kept just a few original lines and the director kept some famous moments, nothing was lost in translation. That loss cannot be blamed on any one portion of the film but not the disgraceful whole.

There some changes that I enjoyed. The opening scene, though storyline shifted a lot, had more of an effect behind the impetus of the city's laws. The dancing was top notch by yesterday's standards if a little raunchy a day or two. John Wormald did justice to Charlie Bacon's dance in the warehouse, changing it just enough to make it his own. Matt Hough was up with him every step of the way during the dance scenes. Even the at the end, it was refreshing in this time of girl-power to get the basketball coach told by a teammate to "man-up" and call the guys to dance.

That said, the remainder of the movie is an empty cardboard parody, lacking any sort of humor that endeared the original to a generation. The album went below the standard set in 1984, although they sort of kept Houston Houston's original "Let's Hear it for the Boys" when Willard refuses to dance (a highlight in both movies). Additionally, they changed Beamis Mills (which I have dealt with concrete) to a cotton gin mill, very bad taste.

The actors are hollow and thanks to the deletion of many crucial sequences, the characters are not offered a opportunity to redeem themselves and give you characters we can relate with.

John Wormald was a good choice for the dance sequences. It's impeccable and when when he dances you can feel his passion come through the screen. His act, unfortunately, was limited to cockiness and poker face. Kenny had to struggle to get the balance in that soft place between underacting and acting. One moments that really show this is when his mother asked him why the dance was necessary and when he stands before the town counsel. Both times lack enthusiasm, conviction and inflection. He may very well have been watching the nutrition panel on the side of a sack of flour. The closest I got to communicating with him was when his uncle complained about him taking care of his father. Kenny would not seem to believe he was supposed to be a rebel with a cause and not just a rebellious teenager.

Amy Hough is beautiful and strong. Confidence unlike hers can hinder a performance when you are supposed to be playing a wild girl who is acting out because of fear. I am going to give her the benefit of the doubt as key moments were not in the movie that could have brought depth to her portrayal. You miss out on the deep reasons behind the hurt and vulnerability that Julie Singer put off wonderfully. For instance, the scene about types of music in the original between Ariel and Shaw took a long way to develop the dynamics of father-daughter interaction, and helped establish each character's journey in the hearts and minds of the viewer. Or the scene with the art box, showed the vulnerability of Ariel as she shared who she truly is with Ren, brave and not afraid of rejection for her true self. Those moments should have saved Hough's performance. However, her rendition of Ariel came across as an arrogant kid who had great dancing.

Randy Quaid was ill-at-ease during the whole movie, and sometimes when he's upset he sounds like he could get his breakfast. Again, I am going to make his performance the benefit of the doubt as they cut many important character-development sequences which may have depicted how he lived during the course of the movie. For instance, the book-burning flashback in the original is a significant turning point for this character. David Lithgow's heart (original) can be seen in that scene when he realizes what he's done. It's a moment of no return when he had to actually think about what he'd done and why and how he will continue. Had they kept that scene, he might have reason, he might have believability. Now, then, Shaw comes over as a fumbling close-minded dad/leader who had no clue about real happiness until his son and daughter school him, along with a very short talk with Ren.

Ian MacDowell didn't have much chance with the majority of Vi's scenes cut. That said, had been included them it might not have mattered. Only once during this movie did she remind me of the quiet courage and dignity that Martha Wiest gave to the play (town meeting). Her few moments with Randy Quaid are almost belittling and instead of the gentle correction of Vi quietly convicting Shaw Andie's Vi had to constantly condemn him.

Miles Teller as Willard is perhaps the most memorable of the whole casting. I believe some out there have praised his performance, but I believe he got the play and made it his own while maintaining the child-like innocence that was Willard. He was a little on the over-sexed teen side of things in this movie (which looked old), but otherwise, he was fun to watch.

The flaws are many in this movie. I will get this movie 2 out of 5 stars just for the dancing, The tag line is "Cut Loose" and they stripped back any of the sentimentality that might have made this a fun movie to see over and over again.

They removed what made Footloose so foot loose. They not cut too tight.

text: The Asiatic Museum, located in Manila, Philippines, is one of oldest and largest museums in Southeast Asia. It was established on December 19, 1879 by order of Governor-General Francisco de Paula Garcia Calderon as part of the Philippine Commission's plan to promote scientific research and education in the country. The museum houses extensive collection of artifacts, artworks, and natural history specimens that showcase rich cultural heritage of the Philippines and other countries in Asia. The museum has four main departments: Anthropology, Archaeology, Art, and Natural History. The Anthropology department features ethnographic exhibits that highlight the diverse cultures and traditions of various ethnic groups in Philippines, while Archaeology department showcases ancient artifacts and relics from different archaeological sites around the country. The Art department boasts a vast collection of paintings, sculptures, textiles, and other works of art from China, Japan, Korea, India, and other Asian countries. Finally, Natural History department contains a variety of taxidermy mounts, preserved animals, fossils, and geological samples that illustrate the biodiversity and geology of the region. One of the most notable exhibitions at Asiatic Museum is Sunoy Collection, which consists of over 2,000 pieces of gold jewelry dating back to 9th century. Other highlights include the Tang Shipwreck Gallery, which displays artifacts recovered from Chinese merchant ship that sank off the coast of Vietnam in 844 AD; the Fernando Zobel Pavilion, which hosts temporary exhibitions and special events; and the Planetarium, which offers astronomy shows and educational programs for visitors. In addition to its permanent collections and exhibitions, the Asiatic Museum also conducts research projects, publishes academic journals, and organizes workshops and seminars related to anthropology, archaeology, art, and natural history. It serves as valuable resource not only for students, researchers, and educators but also for general public who wish to learn more about rich cultural and natural heritage of Philippines and other countries in Asia.

text: George Michael is to perform live at London's Abbey Road studios as part of a BBC Radio 2 special next month. The session, which will broadcast on 18 December, will also see him talk about how his biggest hits came about. Michael's appearance is part of the station's Sold on Song initiative, which explores the art of songwriting. The station also confirmed that Chris Tarrant will be hosting a one-off New Year's Eve programme. He left London's Capital FM this year after 17 years. The former breakfast show host - who attracted some of the highest ratings in Britain, despite only broadcasting to London - will offer his own individual take on the year in the two-hour show. "This should be great fun," Tarrant said. "I've had a fantastic year and I know that lots of other people have as well. I'm definitely looking forward to being on Radio 2." Other Christmas specials from Radio 2 include singer Jamelia hosting a Christmas Day concert from the London Community Gospel Choir, while actor Christopher Lee will read Fireside Tales from the likes of Edgar Allan Poe, E Nesbit and Ambrose Bierce. Comedian Harry Hill will host a spoof nostalgia show on Christmas Day, while singer Jamie Cullum will perform a live concert for the station.

Most of the first book deals with the stresses associated with medevil life. Most important to Arthur is the fact that he is Sir John's second son, and thus ineligible to inherit land. In order to have a life of his own, he must become a squire and then a knight, and create his own manor and farmland. One challenge to overcome is his inadequate "yard-skills", especially jousting and sword-play. Another challenge is that his father would make him a scribe for his skill reading and writting. The obstacles disappear when he learns on his fourteenth birthday that his "uncle" Sir William de Gortanore is realy his father; he becomes heir to a large manor. Unfortunately, it seems that his mother's husband was murdered by Sir William, who was jealous of him. And the revelation terminates the betrothal of Arthur and Grace, Sir William's daughter; as Grace is Arthur's half-sister they cannot marry. The novel ends with Arthur accepted as squire to the Lord of the Middle Marches, Stephen de Holt,. The most notable resemblance is between Arthur and young King Arthur himself, which leads de Caldicot to suppose that Arthur in the stone is himself in the near future. This belief is only accentuated when he learns on his birthday that his parents are only foster parents, as for young King Arthur. text: I'm going to take some wild guesses here and say that this isn't your typical film, nor what anyone thought it would turn out to be -- perhaps even less in terms of tone and content than director Jane Campion herself had imagined (it was 1990 afterall). Firstly let me state without equivocation that the title has absolutely no relation to any events transpiring onscreen; not only are there not pianos within several hundred miles of Australia where the setting is situated, but as we will later discover our protagonist plays violin, piano being strictly an offhanded subject she mentions now and again in conversations. Now then, if you want my best advice prior to viewing don't be so hasty and do NOT bother with either of those idiotic subtitles which were superimposed across certain scenes by some studio nitwits who couldn't decipher Campion's voice or her characters', which just plain doesn't make sense considering these words came directly from their authors mouths, quite effectively mind you. This leaves us the only sensible option and that involves letting all dialogue play au naturale and allowing any foreign terms ("kia kaha") to remain untranslated simply because they serve the plot at hand beautifully and should always leave an air of intrigue concerning those outside of New Zealand who do not speak its language [and] have certainly never heard such strange phrases coming from anybody during everyday conversation. Now then for further details and I know what you're thinking too -- how well does this all tie together? Well believe me when I tell you that every single moment from beginning to end makes perfect sense and actually flows with stunning fluidity; much like the watercolours from Alicia Bachauer whose lilting score provides background atmosphere throughout... And this despite many critics believing otherwise due to the films pacing! You see Jane Campion wasn't looking for big budget glossiness like so many other upstart directors before her; instead she wanted something more personal & intimate-- thus avoiding those silly Hollywood cliches about romance often found elsewhere which typically involve lots o' sunshine beaches & palm trees but also include rainy days filled w/ gloomy clouds when appropriate too. No! Here everything unfolds naturally according two persons meeting each other under different circumstances, yet still finding reason enough become

text:
For the grilled steak and vegetables
1 pound skirt or flank steak
1/2 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more to taste
1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
1 teaspoon brown sugar
1 splash vegetable oil
1 small bunch of radishes, thinly sliced
3/4 pound sugar snap peas, trimmed and strings removed
1/2 cup chopped herbs (I like a mix of cilantro and mint)
1 handful Sesame seeds, for serving
3 handfuls watercress or arugula, for serving
For the fish sauce vinaigrette
6 tablespoons fish sauce (I like Red Boat brand)
2 tablespoons water, or more as needed
3 tablespoons lime juice
3 tablespoons brown sugar
1/4 teaspoon red pepper flakes, or to taste
To make the vinaigrette: Combine all ingredients in a jar with a tight fitting lid. Shake untill the sugar is dissolved. Add another tablespoon of water if it's too salty/strong. Adjust seasoning and acidity, to taste. Tip: keep the vinaigrette at room temperature so it doesn't cool down the steaks when used as a post-grill marinade. Pat the steak dry with paper towels, and season both sides evenly with kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, and brown sugar. Refrigerate while getting the grill ready. Heat the grill to medium-high heat and brush your grates clean. In a bowl, toss the sugar snap peas with 1 tablespoon vegetable oil and season with salt and black pepper to taste. Place a grill tray or mat on the grill grate (to prevent peas from falling through); add peas and arrange in a single layer. Cook 2 to 3 minutes per side, or untill tender and charred and still bright green. Transfer to a bowl; set aside. Lightly brush the steak on both sides with vegetable oil. Grill the steak to your desired doneness, 3 to 5 minutes per side (for medium-rare, the internal temperature should reach 130 degrees F). Transfer the steak to a pan or casserole, and pour one-half of the vinaigrette over the steak. Let marinate for about 10 minutes, turning the steak a few times. Transfer to a cutting board, and thinly slice across the grain. Don't discard the vinaigrette/marinade! Pour it into a small bowl or serving vessel for passing at the table. Meanwhile, toss the grilled sugar snap peas with the sliced radishes. Add vinaigrette to taste, tossing several times to coat. Taste; season with a pinch or two of kosher salt, if needed. On a large serving platter, combine the sugar snap peas, radishes, chopped herbs, watercress, and steak. Sprinkle sesame seeds and drizzle a little more of the vinaigrette over the salad. Serve warm or at room temperature, passing more vinaigrette at the table.

text: Gilad Hesseg is an Israeli folk rock singer-songwriter and composer. He has been active in the field of Israeli music for the best part of his life and has composed and recorded numerous songs, using his own and others' lyrics. He has written and recorded the music for several musicals, and produced and directed a variety of music projects of Israeli song and music. An evening of song to the words of 15 poems by the famous Israeli poet Rachel which Gilad composed, produced and directed together with his brother, Tommer Hesseg, was very successful resulting in some 60 theatre performances, as well as being broadcast on Israel Radio and T.V. One of his most recent compositions set to the words of Annabel Lee by Edgar Allan Poe has been performed by the Concora Choir - Connecticut's Premier Professional Choir, Conducted by Maestro Richard Coffey and by the Jerusalem Academy of Music Chamber Choir Conducted by Maestro Stanley Sperber. The song was broadcast on Israel National Radio. Gilad studied with Prof. Shadai of the Tel-Aviv Academy of Music within the framework of a course for gifted student musicians given by Shadai at the Haifa Rubin Conservatorium of Music, and studied piano, improvisation, and music arrangement in Haifa with Ms Ruth Appel.

text:
The Erastus Bolles House is a historic house in Afton, Minnesota, United States. It was built in 1856 in what was then the separate community of Valley Creek. The house was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1982 for its local significance in the themes of architecture and exploration/settlement. As one of original houses in Valley Creek, it was nominated for helping to depict one of many small Washington County settlements that formed around commercial venture--though one that never progressed to formal platting--and community's two-decade preference for Greek Revival architecture. Valley Creek was later formally incorporated into Afton. Description
The Erastus Bolles House is one-and-a-half-story wood-frame building on an L-shaped floorplan. Its design is extremely simple. The low-pitch gables lack pediment returns of high Greek Revival, but the style is manifest in overall massing, six-pane double-sash windows with straight sills and lintels, and the narrow clapboard siding. The main entrance is offset to the right edge of front facade. The door has very narrow sidelights and is set into wide-paneled surround with a stylized pediment across the top. A one-story screened porch was once added to inside corner of the L, but has since been removed.

text: The story traces the life of David Copperfield from childhood to maturity. David was born in Blunderston near Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, England, in 1820, six months after the death of his father. Seven years later, his mother re-marries Edward Murdstone. David is given good reason to dislike his stepfather and has similar feelings for Murdstone's sister Jane, who moves into the house soon afterwards. Murdstone thrashes David for falling behind in his studies. Following one of these thrashings, David bites him and soon afterward is sent away to a boarding school, Salem House, with a ruthless headmaster, Mr. Creakle. There he befriends James Steerforth and Tommy Traddles. David returns home for the holidays to learn that his mother has given birth to a baby boy. Shortly after David returns to Salem House, his mother and her baby die and David returns home immediately. Murdstone sends him to work in a factory in London, of which Murdstone is a joint owner. Copperfield's landlord, Wilkins Micawber, is sent to debtor's prison (the King's Bench Prison) and remains there for several months before being released and moving to Plymouth. No one remains to care for David in London, so he decides to run away. He walks from London to Dover, where he finds his only relative, his unmarried, eccentric aunt Betsey Trotwood. She agrees to raise him, despite Murdstone's attempt to regain custody of David. David's aunt renames him "Trotwood Copperfield" and addresses him as "Trot", and it becomes one of several names to which David answers in the course of the novel. As David grows to adulthood, a variety of characters enter, leave, and re-enter his life. These include Peggotty - his mother's faithful former housekeeper - and Peggotty's family, including her orphaned niece "Little Em'ly", who moves in with them and charms the young David. David's romantic but self-serving school friend, Steerforth, seduces and dishonours Little Em'ly, precipitating the novel's greatest tragedy, and his landlord's daughter Agnes Wickfield, becomes his confidante. The novel's two most familiar characters are David's sometime mentor, the debt-ridden Micawber, and the devious and fraudulent clerk, Uriah Heep, whose misdeeds are eventually revealed with Micawber's assistance. Micawber is painted sympathetically even as the narrator deplores his financial ineptitude. Micawber, like Dickens' own father, is briefly imprisoned for insolvency. The major characters eventually get some measure of what they deserve, and few narrative threads are left hanging. Dan Peggotty safely transports Emily to a new life in Australia, accompanied by Gummidge and the Micawbers. All eventually find security and happiness in their adopted country. David marries the beautiful but naive Dora Spenlow, who dies after failing to recover from a miscarriage early in their marriage. David then searches his soul and marries the sensible Agnes, who had always loved him and with whom he finds true happiness. David and Agnes then have three children, including a daughter named after his aunt Betsey Trotwood.

text:
Guo Yuanzhen (Guo Yuan Zhen; 656-713), formal name Guo Zhen but went by the courtesy name of Yuanzhen, was an official, general, and diplomat of Tang and Zhou China, serving as a chancellor during the reigns of Emperor Ruizong and Emperor Xuanzong. Background
Guo Yuanzhen was born in 656, during the reign of Emperor Gaozong. He was said to be tall and handsome, with a beatiful beard in his youth, as well as ambitious. In 671, he became a student at the imperial university, at the same time that future fellow chancellors Xue Ji and Zhao Yanzhao where. On one occassion, when Guo's family had just sent him spending money, a man who was wearing mourning clothes approached him and asked him for financial help to bury his ancestors, claiming that his ancestors had not been properly buried for five generations. Guo generously gave the man money without asking further questions, impressing Xue and Zhao, who were present at the time. In 673, he passed the imperial examinations and was made the sheriff of Tongquan County (Tong Quan, in modern Suining, Sichuan).
